Things are very confusing but that’s fine because I’m sure everything will be cleared up eventually right? Nope. It’s never explained why they are there or how they got there. The plot seemed to just forget his sister was dead. We have the whole conflict of “you need to save your sister because she’s going to be dissected.” Um excuse me, what? Did you just say dissected? If that made no sense to you, don’t worry, you aren’t alone. Nobody, and I mean NOBODY would dissect a human being unless they were descended from Dr. Mengele. There is no way this is legal. Even Elfen Lied didn’t go this far. This anime is basically ignoring any pretenses of continuity and realism and discarding them for cheap dramatic effect that falls apart the moment you turn on your brain and THINK about what YOU ARE WATCHING. If this had been going on for a long time, as it has been implied it has, then the government would have eventually found out and shut them down for inhumane experiments. Human experimentation is already illegal. Even if psychics were seen as nothing more than animals, there are still laws in place to protect animals from cruelty, which seems to be what is happening to the psychics, even the ones who aren’t being dissected. It also is in this episode we learn about the main character’s ability to “steal other people’s powers”. Yes, you read that right. This whole time he has had the ability to steal other people’s powers. But then how did he get his power? I suppose his power could have come with the ability to possess them as well, but he certainly used his power on plenty of other ability users. Why did he literally never notice anything different? He he had stolen so many abilities it would have been simple for him to save his sister. It’s implied that Nao at least already knew about this. Why didn’t she just tell him “here take all our powers and go save your sister. While you’re at it, go destroy that research facility since you’re so powerful”. I feel bad for this series’ ass. It must hurt from all the things that were pulled out of it. So then we learn that the main character has a big brother. A big brother that we heard nothing about before. And he can time travel too, but he can’t do it because he’s blind and needs to see in order for it to work. Um excuse me? Why is this? This makes no sense. Then again, the main character needs to be able to see his victims before he can take them over, so many it’s a genetic thing? But then his little sister doesn’t need to see in order to use her ability. Whatever. We never learn anything about the research facility or why the main character’s sister was still alive. I really think the anime just forgot she was dead.

Episode 10 is basically episode 10 of madoka. There isn’t much to say about it. We switch main characters and he goes back in time over and over in order to save the psychics from despair. The episode itself is pretty stupid because we have all these half-assed this set up. Like Mr. Drip doesn’t actually have to be wet in order to use his power. It’s just a disguise. Because nobody would ever recognize him with his hair in his eyes… Then the big brother is like “I know, I’ll disappear from the lives of my family. We’ll just erase their memories.” But how does he erase their memories? No power of memory alteration was mentioned up until now. The guy who goes in and does it is also never mentioned before.  

Episode 12 worked fine as a final episode. All the problems felt resolved although we have this awful romance between the main character and Nao. Just because you have two characters doesn’t mean that they will work together in a romance. This is exactly what happens in Charlotte. Even the characters themselves admit that they don’t work together. I can even remember a scene where the main character watched Nao get beaten by a group of older students and did nothing, despite the fact that he had the power to control them and make them stop. It’s just stupid and cliche. But why is there an episode 13 if episode 12 felt like a such a relatively satisfying ending? Well, your guess is as good as mine. What posessed them to include this episode is beyond me. It would have worked great as a beginning to a second season, but not as a final episode. It felt rushed and pointless. The story was already over. We didn’t need more. Episode 13 is pretty much season two packed into one episode. It was a rushed progression of events that should have had a series all to itself and had no place in this season.



Characters: 1/10

Right up till the very end we are presented with a cast of two dimensional characters who we’re for some reason suppose to care about. We have someone who can teleport, has a creepy obsession with idols, and… that’s about it. He never develops, he never learns from anything. He’s just a cardboard cutout that things happen to. We have Mr. Drip who has to be wet to use his power except no just kidding it’s actually a disguise (like seriously wtf). We have our main character who’s selfish and self-centered only using his power for himself. He’s pretty badass. But then all of that leaves in episode 2 and we never see any of that agian. It’s like the tempted you into it with this pretty sweet MC and cool hook and then went and destroyed any semblance of what could have been good. We have the idol girl, Yusa who’s basically Misa-Misa but with less personality. She can channel the dead, or more specifically, her dead big sister. Her dead big sister has the ability of pyrokinetics. But wait, her dead big sister is at least 20 years old, right? Why does she still have her powers? Whatever. She doesn’t have much more personality than her younger sister. She’s the Action Girl who talks like a man and insults you. It’s been done so many times. Mr. Drip gets almost no personality. His major character trait was “Big Brother’s best friend”, and he doesn’t develop at all. They play his death off as if it were supposed to be super sad and tragic and all I could think was “why on earth am I supposed to care if this guy dies?”. The little sister was cute but could get annoying at times and had no personality other than “genki girl”. Nao is the only marginally interesting character. She has an actual backstory. Sadly, she’s the only good character in the show. I don’t really feel like talking about this anymore, I said most of it in the beginning. The characters are just plain boring, about on par with Sword Art Online characters. In fact, these characters just might be worse.


Art: 8/10

Just like with Angel Beats, the art in this was decent. The character designs were good, although there were times I couldn’t tell some characters apart. Other than that, the general look of things was very pretty. Especially Nao <3


Sound: 6/10

The voice acting was fine, but nothing spectacular. The music was good and fit the scenes and tone very well, but unfortunately wasn’t memorable enough for me to listen to it and say “Ah, that’s Charlotte music”. 


tl;dr this is one of the worst anime I have ever seen in my life. Nothing about it was good. The plot was a mess with Deus Ex Machina and asspulls right and left, more holes than swiss cheese, and poor characters that I cared nothing about. There were more plot holes than I care to count and events so ridiculous that I’m pretty sure an episode of scooby doo would have had more credibility. Watch this anime if you wanna have a good laugh, but don’t expect anything special.

This is my first review so please bear with it.
MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!!
Story: 7/10
Not much to talk about here, simple story, many flaws, both happy and dark at the same time. Strongest point is its ability to catch everyones attention for sure!
Art: 8/10 
The art was good and made the anime easily enjoyable and colored and catchy, definitely one of the strongest points about the anime.
Characters: 7/10
I wouldn't say the character development of this anime was very good but it certainly wasn't bad either, some characters might've been too rushed and that was probably one of the biggest mistakes in Charlotte, the plot is too rushedfrom episode 9 to 13.\n
Characters that have been getting developed for 8 episodes are suddenly switched by poorly developed and boring characters.\n\n
Enjoyment: 9/10\n\n
Although it has a lot of flaws, Charlotte is an easy enjoyable anime all the way through, mostly because of its comedy.\n\n
Overall : 8/10\n\n
It is easy to dislike and like Charlotte, it really depends on what people prefer. I'd definitely recommend it to newcomers mostly, veterans will most likely (not all of them) dislike the anime because of its flaws and too fast pace of changes which brakes the momentum.\n\n\n

Ever heard about those conspiracy theories that go about a selection of people having superhuman powers due to either radiation, extraterrestrial contact, or even going as far as claiming that the government injects experimental substances on our children's vaccines? The world is full of bullshit, the government isn't the least interested in planting micro cameras on your pets to spy on you while doing your creepy weeby shit, but hey, this is Anime. A medium that always entrust the greatest powers to characters in their puberty, the world could never be safer am I right? While the adults are laying on their backs it's alwaysthe kids that save humanity, but hey, speaking of conspiracy theories again, the cartoon "kids next door" might as well be a message from those who are aware of the dark truth, I'm going off of topic here, enough spilling bullshit and let's actually talk about Charlotte.

A series that not surprisingly enough relates to what I was just saying, an original work by studio P.A Works that gets a huge praise from the fans going as far as calling it a masterpiece, and hold on, that's a title very rarely to be obtained by modern works for how repetitive they can get. But does Charlotte fall into that same case? Here we're pealing off the fans' claims, dissecting this series and exposing it for what it is. Buckle up, get comfy, and let's hit the keyboard for some words.


- Story (7.5/10):

First and before anything, this is a story by Jun Maeda, the creator of the both critically acclaimed well established and praised series, Angel Beats and Clannad. Just so you know what you're in for, I for one didn't enjoy Angel Beats at all however digged Clannad so much that I consider the series to be a life changer for me, goes to show that one can only do so much, not all works of an author can be equal, and Charlotte is no exception here.

In a world very similar to our own, some people through their adolescent obtain superhuman powers, like pyrokinesis, telekinesis, teleportation and so on. Otosaka Yuu, the protagonist was living his life like a big fish in a small pot, thinking he was the chosen one and the lone in the world to have powers until he gets exposed to the truth of the world, kids all over the worlds are blessed with very useful abilities, and now he's charged with the help of the student council members that also have powers to try and capture the ones that use their abilities for mischief. A very generic story structure right there.

It does start very slice of life natured and slow, with a lot of focus on comedy until the feel train hits you like a damn "Gamu Gamu no King Kong Gun" when you least expect it, and let's be honest, Clannad and Angel Beats have made that very clear, I'm about to spill some spoilers for Angel Beats here so keep notice and skip the next few lines; there are even theories out there that the protagonist of Angel Beats is the protagonist in Charlotte after he was reincarnated for what they both hold in similarities.

As I was saying, the story was very uninteresting for me for the most part, the score could have been even lower here if it weren't for that humongous plot twist nearing the final episodes, my God, I don't think I've ever been so skeptical and at the same time opening my mouth as a garage door from confusion and astonishment since I last saw the plot twist at the end of Mirai Nikki, shit can get pretty intense at the end, but it still doesn't make up for the poor start, that's where most people drop the series. But it does fill you with satisfaction when you start noticing the hints that were all over the initial episodes that led up to the big bang at the end, for that, I give my props.


- Art (8.0/10):

Because Charlotte is another sibling to Angel Beats, Clannad, (and to drag on the list; Little Busters, Kanon and more...) they adopted a very similar art style in design only in a more modern quality and detail. I'm not a big fan on the massive eyes that take most of the face on the author's older series, but this at least was acceptable, not dragged way too much it's noticeable.

The animation was beautiful, I can't complain about anything, but it was still nothing memorable, interesting enough to keep you visually interested in the story.

I would say that their focus here was on the male cast, the female characters weren't too flashy looking aside from probably a trio that has a lot of screen time, but the males were straight up from a model factory, sorry if that sounded a bit too dark but seriously, everyone looks at least like they could have a harem series with them as the protagonist, going as far as taking the spotlights from the protagonist himself. I surprisingly did enjoy the CGI scenarios in here, I'm glad they didn't over do it, it was very short and that was the charm of it.


- Sound (7.7/10):

The voice acting was okay, with some annoying voices here and there, so glad those ones didn't have too much screentime or my ears would have started bleeding. The only thing I enjoyed was the opening theme song, I wasn't a big fan of the ending theme song but the opening one really did it for me, I know I have extra ammo for my conversation now *wink*. The soundtrack, well, it was too unexciting for me to remember, even the music, the story was a bit heavily focused on music and yet it still didn't hit the spot, even the terrible (Just my opinion) Angel Beats' music were good, at least I can spit that truth out.


- Character (6.0/10):

At the start of the series I was set to giving this aspect of the show a 3, probably a 4 if I felt generous. The characters were too shallow for me, nothing actually stood out from them aside from the flashy character designs, but I ain't letting any colors fool me.

I went through the whole show and I can barely remember 2 names aside from the protagonist's who himself gave me a hard time to remember his name as well, until I made it to the 10th episode or something, yes, that's how uninteresting the cast was, probably the story could have been even better with better characters.

But hey, how did this rise up to 6/10 you ask? well, the protagonist went through a sigh to be seen of a development, I would show you clips from him at the beginning and him near the end and you wouldn't believe me if I told you they were the same person, the change was so massive and noticeable, but it didn't happen overnight which I appreciate. I don't think their names would survive for another day in my head though, the pacing has really dropped since Clannad.


- Enjoyment (8/10):

I was questioning myself when I got midway through the series as nothing special had already happened, but before I realized it, a certain happening occurred, character development started flowing, and a lot of plot points were explained which made the wait worth it. I honestly went from not being interested at all, something very frustrating that this could have been worse than Angel Beats for me, but the twists at the end made me interested yet again in the neck of time, this is something that I would definitely rewatch one of those days.


- Overall (7.4/10):

Well, before anything, please don't let my nagging about how bad I found Angel Beats or my praise on how good Clannad was for me deceive you or give you a clear image on both series if you haven't watched them already, remember those were only my experiences with them, who know, probably I just didn't watch Angel Beats in its respective mood or something, but this is an entirely different series with its own ups and downs. I can't guarantee that you will enjoy at least the first 6 episodes, I know I didn't, but if you could just hang out there at least till past the first six episodes you will have quite the payoff.

At first, I thought Charlotte was seriously going to be one of my favorite anime of all time. I couldn't have been more mistaken.
 like the majority of anime Charlotte starts with an interesting story. Maybe the idea of a school for teenagers with superpowers isn't exactly original, but i find that some anime manage to hit it of from a seemingly stereotypical start, to an entirely original and entertaining end. This process that Charlotte should have and would have done. THAT is the kind of potential that Charlotte showed.
Let's start with the story. The first few episodes were nice. They were very humorous, andi honestly enjoyed more than i would like to admit. The faint smell of mystery hung in the air, which is always a good factor, and something that i find makes the story very attracting. 


At this point, the creators tried to make the story more realistic. How? by making it sad and serious of course! Making a story sad does not necessarily mean that it will be realistic! Oh, and why do people think that the only way to make something sad is by killing people? Honestly! the theme of tragedy was a complete contradiction to the whole concept of this thing.


Now, we're still not quite done from the drama yet! It is now time to fit an arc that should have actually been an entire season by itself, into 3 episodes. Well done! You have failed miserably! This part of the story was waay too rushed, the events were very confusing, and the progression of the plot was awful. It didn't fit.


To top it all, the last episode was the worst of them all.

The ending was just very disappointing, and not well thought. I expected so much more. The beginning was beautiful but the ending was very lacking in depth. they had managed to extract all the comedy and fun the show had.


The only one worth mentioning when talking about the characters was Misa. She was The only one to show development if i recall correctly. I like the rest of the main characters, but they weren't special. they were very normal.

Some of them had the potential to be really well written.


Sound and Art were probably the best things. They were noticeably good.


I admit that i did enjoy the story, but only for the first part, so until around the seventh episode. That's the time the story started going wacko.


Overall, the anime was literally half-and-half. The first part almost spectacular, the second catastrophic. Not exactly a show worth watching.

Just to be clear, this is not a recommendation to watch this show. The plot has no clue what it's doing, the characters are one dimensional, the messages the show gives are actually pretty bad, but despite all of that, I liked it.
The first thing this show did right is kill any expectations I had by setting up an interesting "selfish anti-hero uses a unique power for personal gain" story in episode 1, and then completely abandoning it in favor of a much less original "high school for super powers" setting with a reluctant hero that isn't actually reluctant beyond very minor complaining. At thispoint, if you have any illusions this show is going to be good, you're nuts, I stayed for one reason and one reason only: I thought teleportation guy was funny.


Then, in episode 6, it throws its premise out the window yet again and at this point, I'm just in awe. It's like this was written by one of those kids that makes up stories as they go, it doesn't make any sense, but that just makes you want to know what they say happens next, and it does not disappointed, with no fewer than 4 random twists that are so out of left field I was laughing out loud at some points.


Now, this level of inconsistency would not have worked if the show felt like it was trying to con me in any way. The reason I enjoyed it was because it made me believe it was actually trying, which led me to give it at least some benefit of the doubt. As an example, there were 2 1/2 cute high school girls in the show (and a little sister), and not a single time was there any attempt to try to set up a love triangle. That would've been an easy source of drama, but the writer just wasn't interested in telling that kind of story.


It's still a bad show of course, but my point is this show gets a bad rap, even a bad show can endear itself to you, and that's what happened for me this time

**May contain spoilers**
(Before you read any further. This is a review based on my opinion. If you disagree with me that's fine, but if you were expecting an objective review then I suggest you stop reading right now)
''The scars you can't see are the hardest to heal...'' ~ Nao Tomori 
I did some research before I started watching Charlotte and I came to the conclusion that people had mixed feelings about this show. One adores the show and the other thinks it's wasted potential. I mean Charlotte is composed by the same person who composed Clannad (After story), Angel Beats and Kanon. Nonetheless this reviewis about Charlotte and not about Clannad. I will use some examples in this review, but it will not influence my judgement. 


Story - 7/10

I really enjoyed the story the first seven episodes. In my opinion Charlotte started as a masterpiece, but they decided to do something different after episode 7. I can respect that, because it is hard to create something original in the modern world. I was still very interested where this show was going. Not much later the concept of ''time leaping'' is introduced and I thought that Charlotte was going to be another time-travel-story. Another episode later it became something different. While the story changes every episode the writers are trying to force a love-story down our throat. Now don't get me wrong I think the main characters are perfect for each other and their chemistry is spot on. There's one main issue with the story. Just like Angel Beats it should have been more than 13 episodes. If Charlotte had more episodes it coud have been much more. The special episode made me hunry for more and they should have used that to their advantage. Since Charlotte originally has 13 episodes and 1 special I can't give the story higher than a 7 much to my regret.


Art - 8/10

The art was amazing, but it wasn't anything special. If you want to see an Anime (movie) with an amazing art-style you should watch Your Name or the Garden of Words. There's not much else to say about the art.


Sound - 8/10

I did like the OP and the OST for Charlotte, but just like the art-style it wasn't anything special in my opinion. I do like the songs by  the ''post-rock band Zhiend'' and the way they were used in Charlotte. 


Character - 8/10

I never hated the main character nor did I like him. I don't really like watching perfect people (even if it's an anime), but the character development was very noticeable. I enjoyed watching the main character changing from an emotionless jerk to a loving and caring person. It is a little bit cliché, but does that make it a bad anime? The other main character was very likeable. Their chemistry really works, but their romance seems a bit forced. I don't like to compare, but since the same person composed Angel Beats, you can't deny the fact that both Charlotte and Angel Beats rushed the romance between the main characters. Therefore the ending feels less nostalgic then it should have. 


Enjoyment - 9/10

Despite the rushed romance and lack of episodes, I still enjoyed Charlotte. Even though the story was rushed near the end, I still feel they handled it better than Angel Beats did. I really enjoyed the chemistry between the main characters and even the humor in some episodes. Like I said I don't wish to compair shows, so I will rate Charlotte as a standalone anime. 


Overall - 8/10

I know I may seem a bit generous, but just like I said this is based on my opinion and I was never trying to be objective. I enoyed Charlotte, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone. If you enjoyed Angel Beats or don't mind watching something incomplete then look no further. The ending is satisfying nonetheless, but it could have been much more. Now don't get my wrong. The length of a show doesn't always guarantee its succes, but in this case I'm absolutely sure it would have improved this show by miles. Therefore I can't rate Charlotte higher than an 8. 


(If you disagree with me or don't like my review then please let me know.)

I finished this a while back, and now it is sort of a classic for me. It took me just one day to finish it, since I really liked the story. I liked it because it was action-based and had a plot that I could follow without getting bored or being overwhelmed by all the details and characters. The plot was very good, and it had a good amount of romance without it taking the spotlight away from the actual story. It was an anime that I really enjoyed! So, if you're looking for an action anime with a hint of romance, I definitely recommendCharlotte.

There are reasons why I started watching this anime. My main reason is it feels somewhat similar to X-Men (the American movies) and as a big fan of X-Men, I just had to watch this. My obvious second reason is the fact that it's made by KEY and directed by Jun Maeda. Am I disappointed? Do I love this show? You'll find out soon enough..
(There will be some SPOILERS in my review)
[Story]: (6/10) (SPOILERS)
The story centers around the special abilities that occur among a small percentage of boys and girls in puberty. Yuu Otasaka uses his powers without others knowing, and lives a fairly normal,average high school life. Before him suddenly appears a girl, Nao Tomori. Due to his meeting with her, the fate of special power-users will be exposed.


*sigh* This is one of the most overhyped anime I have ever seen and I do understand why.. It's directed by Jun Maeda, the man behind Angel Beats and Clannad, and it's also made by Key. The company behind Angel Beats, Clannad: After Story and Little Busters: Refrain. Since this is being made by a company who made one of my favourite animes of all time, how could I not be hyped for this show? The first few episodes started out strong.  We are introduced to the MC who apparently has a special powers. He was then taken in by a girl named Nao Tomori and you now have a school full of teens who has a special power. I thought that at this point, they were going to follow the route of X-men where Charles built a special school for mutants. Not really..


Then the 2nd half came (Ep. 6-10) which was honestly the great part of the series. It had a drastic turns of event where Yuu's little sister died, Yuu dealing with aftermath of her death and Nao saving him from his depression.  I was even happy when they found out that they , or rather, he can save Ayu from her death. That was one of the most sweetest moments evar! Somewhere around the 2nd half, you'll notice that the pacing is starting to become an issue. They even had to skip the openings but that still didn't solve the problem. 


Then the last 3 episodes came which was the most disappointing episodes I have ever seen in my life. After watching the last 3 episodes, I told myself that Charlotte should have ended on Episode 10 because Episode 11-13 felt unnecessary. They decided to add in this terrorist organization which ended up becoming stupid because they weren't even explained that well. Where in the mother of god did they come from? What was their purpose? The answer is....where's the answer? Oh that's right, it wasn't answered because the show is plagued with plot holes. That's right...plot holes and there are a lot of them. I'm going to give you guys a few examples. Who exactly were the terrorists? How did they know about Yuu's ability? Who exactly are these "scientists" that kidnaps teens with special powers? So did Ep. 8 happen or not? Yuu time leaped and saved Ayu which means he never entered a depression which also means he never met the ZHIEND vocalist. Which ALSO means she never sang for Nao's brother. Which also f*cking means that Nao's brother is still in a f*cked up state. 


Then came the ending... I'm going to make this short. It's VERY RUSHED. Who in their right mind came up with an idea to make Yuu go around the world and make him loot every ability in 1 episode? They could have made a second season and dedicate 12 episodes of him travelling around the world, meeting new people and plundering abilities at the same time and make the 13th episode of him getting saved by his older brother and returning to Nao. If second season isn't possible for them then they could have made a different ending. Instead we got a shitty lackluster and very rushed ending. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Art/Animation]: (10/10)

The anime was also created by PA Works who happens to have the 2nd best animation in the anime industry, behind ufotable. Anyways, the animation looks amazing. You can see that the environment is drawn well like the buildings, the ground, the roads, etc, and the glare in the sun is amazing, etc. The character design looks somewhat similar to Angel Beats but better. 

Lastly, the animation looked smooth and I didn't really spot any choppiness. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Sound]: (9/10)

Most of my soundtrack rating comes from the inserted songs, the OP and the ED theme songs. The show amazed me in 2 out of 3 categories. 


The OP theme song is Bravely You by Lia and there are 3 ED theme songs which are "Yake Ochinai Tsubasa" by Aoi Tada , Rakuen made" by Yusa Nishimori, and "Kimi no Moji" by Anri Kumaki. The OP theme song is awesome. Especially that soothing voice in the middle of the OP song. All the ED theme song sounds great but the 3rd ED theme is the best. Too bad, it didn't fit quite well in the show because of how rushed the ending is. 


The Voice Actors did a great job with their characters. Especially Nao Tomori. I just love her voice!


I'm probably the only guy here who hated the inserted song that was sung by one of the ZHIEND vocalist "Sara Shane". It sounded like someone was puking inside my ear. I just had to skip it when she sung it for the second time. Here's a tip, hire a singer who can actually sing in English.. I mean, Lia...the singer for the OP theme song have also sung some songs in English. Her English sounded fluent. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Characters]: (6/10) (SPOILER)

This is one of those shows that could have been a lot better in terms of Character Development if it had more episodes. Yuu is basically the only character who got a major character development. Nao and the rest of the supporting characters got little to none. Yuu from the start is this cheating asshole who uses his ability to......well...cheat his way up and get girls in the easiest way possible. Then after his sister died, we get to see him in his depression state which is, in my opinion, a great part to watch. You can feel what his going thru and it really depressed the hell out of me. When Nao gave him a rice omelette with a pizza sauce, I broke down at that point. Whatever, the point here is Yuu went from an unlikable character to a likable character because it shows that he really cares for his sister and he wants her back in his life. The last 3 episodes switched him back to an unlikable character, especially the f*cking ending.  


I did say that the supporting characters got little to no development right? That's right. For example, Yusa's flashback ain't even that sad because it wasn't enough time to establish a dramatic feeling with that character. Same goes for Pooh's (Kumagami) death. He just didn't get enough screentime for me to feel sad about his death. I gotta admit, Ayu's death did depress me...a bit. 


One last thing, it's Yuu's and Nao's confession. In my opinion, it was hilarious and one of the best confessions I have ever seen in my life. If you know Nao then you should know that she's a cold b*tch..*ahem* I mean a cold chick. I wasn't exactly surprised at Nao's reaction because that's her personality from the start. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Enjoyment]: (8/10)

To be honest, I did enjoy this show quite a bit even though the plot in the end turns into a cluster f*ck. The typical "baseball game" is there since this is a KEY anime, the funny moments are also present (i.e Yusarin's hilarious moments), and etc. Nao is also one of my favorite characters so seeing her in action is quite enjoyable to watch.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[OVERALL]: (7/10)

"Charlotte" seriously had the potential to become one of my favorite KEY animes but sadly, the 13 episode count ruined it. The story wasn't even that bad. The show just suffered from horrible pacing, little character development and a very rushed ending. If the series had 25 episodes then this would have been a great show. 



Pros:

+Decent Story

+Outstanding Animation

+Great OP and ED theme songs

+Great Soundtrack

+Decent Characters


Cons:

-Pacing issues

-Supporting characters, including most of the main characters, got little to no character development.

-Show is plagued with plot holes

-Unexplained Terrorist group near the end

-Very Rushed Ending

-Pointless Episode 8

Story: 5/10
Art & Sound: 9/10
Characters: 3/10
Enjoyment: 7/10
Overall: 5/10
If you were a fan of either of Jun Maeda's previous works - be it Clannad, Little Busters, Air etc - or just a fan of Key in general, there was every reason to get excited for the release of Charlotte. This held especially true for me - Angel Beats! has been a mainstay under the Favorite Anime section of my profile, ever since I finished it in January last year. Despite being prepared to be astounded and amazed by what was arguably the most hyped anime of Summer 2015, I instead met with mediocre plot execution andsubstandard character development. So where exactly did Charlotte go wrong? 


STORY - 5/10 


Being an ardent fan of the super power genre, I loved the idea behind Charlotte. A story about young teenagers possessing mystical powers and putting them to use for a cause seemed to be my ideal anime. Unfortunately, Charlotte was simply too rushed to truly appreciate. From as early as after the third episode, many parts and scenes in the Charlotte storyline requiring in-depth elaboration to enjoy was packed and compressed rather tightly into just a mere 24 minutes. And shall we ignore the plot holes and way-too-conveniently-timed incidents that seemed to poke out every so often? Although, overlooking it's dreadful pacing and somewhat ridiculous incidental occurrences, there were still various interesting bits and pieces in the entire anime. Having just 13 episodes does this anime a disservice, mostly because the fascinating plot behind it might have been a revelation if expanded into a 2-cour series or even more. 


ART & SOUND - 9/10


Art & sound may just be two of the greatest, if not the best points of Charlotte. As expected of PA Works, the studio behind recognizable titles like Nagi no Asukara and Shirobako delivered, bringing the crisp animation and beautiful backgrounds that I had relished from their previous works. The soundtrack was largely on point as well, but I have to give special mention to How-Low-Hello, or rather, Maaya Uchida, whom I felt did a great job with the second ending theme 'Rakuen made', as well as the insert song 'Hatsunetsu Days'. The regular ending and opening themes are also fantastic and fit the anime very well. We can't forget about ZHIEND either, a post-rock band in the anime also responsible for a few of Charlotte's many insert songs. I can't profess to being a fan of post-rock, but I enjoyed ZHIEND's tunes and I'm sure I'm not the only one. All in all, Charlotte possesses some very splendid art and sound, and it is perhaps those that make this show stand out in a positive manner.


CHARACTERS - 3/10


Can the same be said about the people that make up the Charlotte universe? Far from it. The characters weren't bad, no, but most of them received little to no development and insight into their personality. As a result, most of the characters in Charlotte came off to me as extremely bland, forgettable, and plain uninteresting. This made it hard to feel emotional and empathize with the characters whenever they had tearful and dramatic moments meant to stir and make an impact on the anime's viewers. 


I shall refrain from going through every single character in Charlotte, but I can list one prominent example of a character not getting his deserved screen time and background information. Under this anime's MyAnimeList page, you will see a certain Joujirou Takajou being listed as a 'main character'. That, I can assure you, is one of the biggest lies I have ever seen. 


If you're reading this at this very moment and you've already watched Charlotte, you may even question: who in the world is Joujirou? Indeed, this character was so easily forgettable that I had to look in the Characters section to remember his name. In spite of the other main characters receiving at least a decent overview of their backstory and history before the events of the anime, this guy suffered the fate of being the comic relief character from start to finish, and no one really knows who he is except for 'that one dude who runs fast'. Main character? Sure...


There isn't much to say about the rest of the main cast either, with about half of them quickly losing their importance within the anime and fading out to become just another background character, which is a pity, because the entire set of main heroes and heroines really piqued my interest at first glance. 


ENJOYMENT - 7/10 


For all it's faults, I liked Charlotte and that is something I can't deny. I was thoroughly in love with it's first few episodes, save for a rather absurdly-paced Episode 3, and looked forward to catching it's latest episode every week. The quality of it seemed to drop week after week though, and the end of the anime culminated in a rather average 7/10 score for me. 


OVERALL - 5/10 


I rate the animes in my anime list based on my enjoyment of it and nothing else, but my unbiased opinion of Charlotte would be nothing more than just a bare passing grade. The animation, sound tracks, and cute girls are a big plus, but ultimately that's not nearly enough for an anime to be able to call itself great. 


This isn't something I would recommend to anime enthusiasts, but maybe to greenhorns new to the wonderful world of anime, who can't exactly differentiate between what's good and what's bad. Contrary to popular belief, it is very possible to get a kick out of average shows especially if you haven't seen enough actual good shows to make the necessary comparisons. Just look at how many people describe Sword Art Online as an anime masterpiece. 


Lastly, I would like to thank you for taking the time to read this review. It's my first one and I would definitely appreciate constructive feedback on how to better them :)

You know, while I was watching Charlotte I really struggled to find the overall point of the whole thing. When it started I considered it to be a "Boku no hero" thing where the protagonist slowly realised he was the strongest of all the cast. Then, I thought it was going to be an Angel Beasts kind of thing, where the main cast was going to be a goofy set of predictable cast members where nothing really significant happens. THEN I thought it was going to be a sort of... well, nothing really, the plot at this point kind of felt typical of an animebut it really wasn't. I can't really explain it. Charlotte isn't really that typical at all. At best I could compare it to a discount Steins'; Gate with a touch of Code: Geass and a smidge of Boku No Hero: Academia. Very... Very... Discounted...


As to be expected from the devils that conceived the well recieved darlings that are Angel Beats and Clannad, this anime is an absolute bastion of unfairness and gimmicky comedy. From stage one you find yourself laughing at the simple interactions between the two main cast however you will also find yourself quite bored of the directionless plot and limited scope, it begins to feel a lot like the Mushishi plot, where nothing really happens despite the constantly interesting interactions between the constant and temporary cast. At stage two you find the "stein's gate" problem, where everything gets complicated however the stakes aren't really as severe, as the most significant problem in the series is solved and the whole thing is turned into an underdog movement despite very little build up or a very explosive conclusion. In fact, speaking of build up, There was no real segway from our first plot to our second one.


Despite whatever I might say this is an incredibly enjoyable experience. with an unnaturally dramatic conclusion. It goes from 0 to 100 in literally 2 episodes, however, I find the difference between episode 2 and episode 12 a massive improvement, its gradual but it is indeed noticeable. If there's any advice that I can give to viewers of this anime then it has to be: Stick with it. Despite the fact the conclusion is in no way as dramatic or as tear-jerking as something as Clannad or as purely joyful as BnHA, you have to appreciate the intricacy of the storytelling involved here and the sheer abuse of the character development involved. There is also a lot of emphasis on sacrifice in this amine, from the least significant to the most significant (at least in terms of development and plot direction). It really is a miracle how much of an attachment is formed between two characters who seemed so distant from each other (but I suppose that's another trope of the industry). In the end, a subjective happy ending was pulled off and I can't be more grateful for it. The story became grim and the grim became great, I don't think you could ask anything more of a well-composed story, especially if you're someone who hates sad stories.



This anime is good, worth a watch unless you haven't watched a total record breaker like Clannad. Be patient and enjoy the middle/climax of the story.

Charlotte, is deep inside, a love in disguise.
The story is simple itself and entertaining with the characters' quirks when they use their incomplete superpower and the catch phrase " such a turn-off " is used to describe the sudden change of the fan boys. It's a comedy and romance enveloped by a mystery that keeps the story going. But there is one important factor that has deepen my interest, which is the chemistry between the Yuu, Ayumi and Tomori and their interaction where they complete each other.
It portrays a romance love where one stands by your side without you knwoing and kick you up fromthe abyss of despair when you're at the edge of losing sanity. A romance love of how deep simple words such as " thank you " can represent the whole grateful and complicated feelings that are bursting inside to reach your heart. Can you love someone if they do not have any memory of you?


It also portrays a brother's dedication and love to his sister, not the brother-sister complex type but a pure love of appreciating her and protecting her with all his might. A love that transcends words and could make you feel warm inside your heart but sometimes it can be so fragile that it could slip right through your grip without you realising it. Can you cry while eating a sweet omelette rice?


All in all, I love how the OST is constructed but the outro is more amazing for me as the song fits perfectly to the pictures and the art is simply beautiful and breath-taking, without any animation that attempt to interpret or explain a feeling in details. Overall, you can expect this anime to have some drama, superpower element, moments to laugh to, romance and of course, moments where your heart resonates with the characters'. 


The two questions mentioned can be simply explained, but the answer itself contains quite some emotions and I'd rather you find it out your way. It's always that when we lose something, then we would regret not appreciating it. It's our flaw as a human, but it also makes us appreciate our loved ones more because we know how deep the pain can be.

When I finished watching this anime I was very disappointed. Reading the description I got very excited and I thought it was the perfect anime for me. Its all over the place when it comes to development and it seems very rushed. I really did enjoy this anime and I would recommend it but I wouldn't get my hopes up. I went into this show really wanting to like it.  I have enjoyed other works by Key such as Clannad, Air, and Kanon (2006), but this anime unfortunately falls into the meh category for me along with Angel beats.
Story: 6/10
While I can't dive into plot too much without major spoilers think of something like X-men where certain people have abilities but are targeted for having them by organizations, syndicates etc. This leads our group of characters to try and stop others from using their powers so they are not targeted.  Plot-wise it felt kinda generic and none of the "sad" Key moments reallygot to me all that much.  I feel like they had a good idea, but the execution could've been better, especially in the later half of the series when the plot gets more convoluted and generally just feels like way too big a jump from the start of the series.  I liked the mysterious nature of the plot in the beginning, but as I figured out more and more, the less interested I became. 


This is probably the "darkest" Key work I've seen to date, but beyond that I don't have much else to add for story.


Art 9/10 and Sound 7/10

The artwork was fine.  No complaints there.  The music was alright.  Lots of Engrish later on in the series but that's typical of a lot of anime anyways.


Character 5/10

The characters, on the other hand, were nothing special save for the protagonist.   Most of the seemed like generic anime stereotypes, and the focus shifts from the main characters and his buddies to a whole new cast of characters halfway through, leaving little room for development.  The main character is the only saving grace here, as you see all the events that change him as a person throughout the story.  Don't expect anything revolutionary here.


Enjoyment 7/10

I did generally enjoy this for the most part.  I knew this was probably not going to be a life-changing show going in, and I was right.  I was interested in the plot in the beginning, but at the series went on it was more just "sure why not?" moments for me.  Again on par with my enjoyment of Angel Beats (this shows seems almost too similar in a lot of regards to it actually).  I'm not sure if I'd watch it again, but it was a fun little show that kept me hooked enough to keep going at the very least to find out what would happen next.


Overall 7/10

If you liked Angel Beats, you'll probably like this.  Definitely not my favorite work from Key, but it was worth the watch at least for my curiosity (this show is pretty popular on this site so I wanted to know why).  I'd say give it a watch.  You might end up liking it a lot, and their are definitely some touching and emotional moments to be had if you get into it enough.  If you hate it, well it's short anyways so you didn't waste that much time anyways.

Introduction:
To be perfectly honest, it's hard to come to a definite conclusion about this show. Is it good? Is it terrible? Could it have done better? Or, more accurately, SHOULD it have done? For now, I'll leave that judgement to you, whether you've seen it or not. If you haven't, just bear in mind that there's an awful lot of debatable things about this show. With that in mind, let's get on with this.
(Scroll to the bottom if you only want a summary)
Main review:
I had semi-high expectations going into this show. The writer, Jun Maeda, has written some pretty excellent stuff in the past. Thevisual novel "Little Busters!" is the main one that springs to mind, as well as Key's other visual novels "Air", "Kanon" and (as much as I may hate it) "Clannad". There's definitely potential for something good. However, given that it was 13 episodes, I feared it may take the same route as "Angel Beats!", an anime also written by Maeda; completely rushed and incomplete. Unfortunately, it looks as if I was right.


If we dissect the show apart, the base story is sound - it had the potential to be a classic Maeda masterpiece. Sure, you might argue that it's not totally original (I'm looking at you, "Angel Beats!") but it hardly matters if it differentiates itself and is amazing. 


The base story, however, is where the positive part ends and where we move onto the main flaw with this show - its painful rushing. There are a fair few completely illogical scenes throughout the show; I won't spoil anything for you but here's an improvised example of what it might look like:


Person 1: -crying- My dog's been put down! I loved my dog so much I don't know what to do! Help me!


Person 2: Just move on and get on with your life. Don't worry about it.


Person 1: (suddenly filled with enthusiasm) Wow you're right, thanks!


Does it make any logical sense? Not really. Given the proper time and effort I'm sure scenes that look like this would be ironed out. Unfortunately for us, there's a 13 episode time constraint and we have to live with it.


On top of that, there's very little time for character development. It mainly just rushes straight through the story leaving no time for anything else. That's not their fault, mind you, but regardless it is hugely detrimental. There's a tiny amount of it, but not enough to consider "acceptable" no matter what your definition of it is.


The other massive issue that ties in with the above point is its inane comedy. It occasionally detracts from what could possibly be a good scene for story/character development and, in other situations, simply wastes the already limited time they have synthesising the show. This is not the kind of show that needs heavy comic relief. Maybe in very small quantities - definitely not the ubiquitous presence it was given. 


Considering all these flaws, you might think it mad that I've given it a 7. For whatever reason, I still really enjoyed it; I managed to watch it more quickly than anything else I've ever seen and I'm still trying to figure out why.


Moving away from the story, the artwork makes this show shine more than it probably should. Personally, I really liked it and it's probably one of the main reasons I got through it so quickly. Its great aesthetics are worthy of its potential - it's a shame it never got realised. As for the OP/ED, they were alright. Nothing worth paragraphing about.



Summary:


On the whole, this show is seriously full of potential. It's not the most original, but it doesn't have to be. Unfortunately, it's very poorly executed due to time constraints and makes the show a bit of a mediocrity rather than the masterpiece it should be. Its artwork holds a lot of value and is probably the best thing about the show since its story isn't fully realised.


Do not be disheartened, however. "Charlotte" may still live up to its full potential. With "Angel Beats!", there's a visual novel version being published in parts by Key, the visual novel studio that Maeda works for. I haven't read it, but I'm willing to bet that it brings out what "Angel Beats!" should have actually been. Hopefully, at some point, the same happens with Charlotte. Thank you for taking the time to read this.


Any comments/advice are appreciated so that I can write better reviews in the future.

First of all I wan't to say that this show was not in anyway a masterpiece but I still found this anime to be enjoyable. I saw a lot of disappointment related to this series before and almost didn't watch it at all. So thinking there might be other people like me out there who might consider not even trying this because they only see the bad stuff written about this in the internet I felt it was needed of me to write this review.
For me the biggest problem was the start. It was prolonged a bit too far just to set up the basisfor the 'student council work' that in the end was not all that essential for this anime. However it did give chance to get to know the characters better and around episode 6 I felt like they had finished "laying the foundation" and the plot started to really progress. I was hooked and just had to see it all the way 'til the end. 


I was thinking that I'm not going to focus on every aspect (art, sounds, characters etc.) separately but just try to express my feelings in words for the series as a whole. Though maybe I should mention few pointers that I noticed. 


Art: if you've seen Aniplex shows before you pretty much know what to expect. Nothing all that amazing but solid animation all the way.


Sound: I liked both OP and ED but in some of the background music sometimes had these weird sounds on regular intervals that at least for me disrupted the feeling of the situation and got me annoyed. Still just a minor annoyance that didn't happen more than few times. 


Generally speaking: Though having some cliché elements I found the way this story was told to be to my liking. I have always enjoyed this "situation based" humor that is typical to anime and what the first half of this anime offers a lot. Staring glowing eyes under a dark cloud from other guys who feel jealous, people rambling about their target of admiration and then getting treated accordingly for this overly stupid behavior are some of the small things I enjoy seeing in so called school-anime. This show delivered that but if you are expecting only school anime that has, synopsis quote: "The student council of the school, led by Nao, is tasked with secretly tracking down adolescents who abuse their powers." you should brace yourself because this show will turn a bit more drama focused around the halfway point. 

The second half of the show focused on dealing with the problems that the characters have mostly because of these abilities and how they are trying to deal with the situation. There was also more than one plot twist that I did not see coming and they made this show more interesting.


I don't want to ramble for too long and accidentally write spoilers so for short conclusion: Despite a bit slow start that had some wasted screen time I think this story was well told in 13 episodes. The main reason why this anime got 7/10 from me instead of better score was that there could have been more focus on character development and that there some rushing in telling the story which was even more evident flaw after slow start. Despite these problems I still found the overall enjoyment to be 'good' hence 7/10


My first ever review. I hope it will be helpful to somebody

When I first heard of this anime i was interested to start watching it , it was written by the same team behind Angel Beats ! one of my favorite series as well as being an original title. When i finished the anime all it did was leave a sour taste in my mouth. 
Story : 
The first 8 episodes were actually decent and enjoyable for me , there was actually build up  and character development throughout those 8 epsiodes with tons of interesting character interactions among the characters. Not only that , there was actually a sense of progression which was sorely lackingin the second half. However i really felt like the encounters with the other ability users could have been cut shorter instead of dedicating an entire episode to it but that might just be me. 


Now for the episodes after 8 or what i would like to call the 2nd half , the 2nd is actually a lot darker which was a change i personally really liked , but was it executed properly ? Hell no, everything was off in the 2nd half. The pacing was incredibly poorly done , everything was going so fast that it left you overwhelmed with question it never truly answers. It also undoes everything the first 8 episodes were building up for and then proceeds to throw all the character development down the drain. This was personally something i couldn't look past , why make something major that changed all the characters then proceed to take all the impact that it had away by undoing it ? 


Next is the ending , Oh. My. God. How could someone actually write an ending like this  and release it is beyond me. I have no idea how to describe it to you since this is an entity on its own. Go watch it and you will know what i mean. 


Characters : 

My main problem with this anime actually lies on its characters and while i enjoyed the main characters and their interactions with others i have to say that aside from 2 characters which was Nao and Otosaka none of the others were given enough development to make me actually feel attached to them at all and this is due to the massive influx of characters that the show keeps on pouring in as the episodes progressed. An example would be Ayumi , being a major character that played a part in progressing the story , she was given so little screen time and development that i really didn't care or felt attached at all to her character. She was the typical little sister character that was there for the sake of being there , same goes to the majority of characters in the anime , they are given so little development and was just there for the story to move forward which is disappointing coming from the people who made Angel Beats.


Art :

One of the saving points of this anime is actually its art and animation , the characters were designed pretty well and backgrounds were beautifully made. There were some scenes where i just paused and observed how beautifully drawn the background , some fighting scenes were insanely well animated as well so kudos to the people behind the art and animation you guys deserve a cookie.


Sound: 

The voice actors actually did a really decent job in voicing the characters , all of them sounded like i expected them to sound which was a huge plus for me. The OST and songs that were used for the OP and ED were also pretty amazing and this is definitely one of the merits of this show


Overall : 


While i enjoyed some parts of this show I couldn't look past the faults to give it a score higher then 5/10. I left the show with a ton of questions and was given an ending that left me unsatisfied , perhaps it could have done a better job with 24 episodes but at its current state a 5/10 is all i could give it.

Spoiler Free, this is my first review so bear with me.
Intro
Charlotte is a perfect example of how anime should be, as an Otaku myself I recommend this anime to anyone who wants a good story line, and a punch in the face of feels.
General Overview
If you are reasonably new to anime you may not have known that the creators of Clannad and Angel Beats developed this work of art so I was expecting a very good story but I got more. Charlotte is an anime where you go in expecting something nice, but come out being more than satisfied as everything is not what itseems. 


for the first 1 - 5 episodes at first you expect this series to be light hearted and very comedic, Charlotte knows when to be serious with drama and action and when to be comedic, therefore it doesn't create awkwardness. 


On the 6th episode said event takes place and changes the anime completely, although the problem is resolved within one episode that is why some people are upset with the story progression, as it could be better.


After the 6th episode, the story progression becomes amazing, it is not something you expect, and it is written out so good, it is mainly the story which captured me into watching and loving this series. 

Some people criticize this anime saying that it is unoriginal, it may contain some elements of angel beats or Clannad at some times, but it is still an original work of art, the story is more than original I haven't seen or heard a story such as this before with the plot twists and the progression, its amazing.


Pros and Cons:


First lets start with the bad, the character development for some said characters could be better, as after some event takes place on a certain character the writers don't take much time to connect you to the person, but instead it shows the main character eating and enjoying food, no death flags at all. 

And some characters don't get enough screen time, and lastly it is slightly rushed, the series would be even more perfect if they spent more time developing characters and making the series longer.


Now the good, the art was beautifully drawn,

every scene had me very satisfied, and the music, when the scene is tense or sad, the music would capture you into the scene,

the story was original and had me at the edge of my seat the whole entire time. Again I come to the music, the ED and the OST are stunning, I've even after finishing the series gone back and listened to them and downloaded some of the OST's.


Story: 9/10

Art: 10/10

Sound: 10/10

Character: 8/10

Enjoyment: 10/10

Overall 10/10

I was looking for a fun short anime to watch while bored one weekend, instead I came across charlotte an emotional rollercoaster with all its twists and turns at every corner. When you expected one thing to happen the complete opposite happened. This anime had it all from romance to time travel. Personally I enjoyed it much more than expected. 
The story at times felt as if one thing was supposed to happen but the producers changed their minds at the last moment. I think that it would have been better to drag some themes out a little more than having them resolved in 1or 2 episodes like when Yuu was grieving over a loss of someone. Most things that happened had little explanations and kept you guessing what could happen next or how it got resolved later down. Charlotte may have been better as a 25 episode anime in my opinion which would have made the pacing a little better. The way that the story concluded was nice as everything was wrapped up leaving only some minor plot holes.


Yuu started off as a guy who would use anyone and cheat his way into life but he quickly changed when he was forced to leave his school and join another school and the student council. His power was originally to be able to control another person for 5 seconds. Nao, the character who forced him to join the student president often wondered around recording things, having the ability to turn invisible to one person at a time was the main love interest to Yuu. Yusarin is a pop idol who has the ability to be possessed by the dead would often get possessed by her dead sister Mira who had the ability to create fire, she had an interesting concept but the character could have had more development alongside Joujirou who can sort of teleport. Joujirou comes across serious at first but is supposed to be more comedic than comes out to be as I found it funny at the start every time he'd crash land or fanboy over Yusarin but it got old quick. The final main character is Yuu's younger sister Ayumi who also served comedic purposes when interacting with her brother but later on she seemed more like plot armour for the series than an actual person. 


The Art style was pleasant to view and the opening was really good along with the ost.


Overall I enjoyed the anime and would recommend it to someone looking for a short dramatic, emotional anime to watch for a couple of hours



Story 9

Art 9

Sound 8 

Character 7

Enjoyment 10

I started Charlotte, as usual, because the opening was nice. I haven't read anything about it and Lia had a great song. I didn't expect a lot, and with that in mind I decided to give it a chance.
Story: 8/10
It's a nice story, for me it has a new concept (faulty superpowers) and that was good enough. The story itself is quite entertaining, it has some interesting moments, touching and funny. It's not Hamlet or Othello, but it's good enough to binge watch it.
Art: 8/10
Not bad, not memorable. A nice color pallete, dark when it must be, light and happy when needed. The characters arewell designed, it does not abuse fanservice to cover flaws. There are not missed frames, there's no abuse of CGI. It's a nice anime.


Sound: 7/10


As I said, the opening caught my attention, and the BGM is nice. But it's not wonderful, you won't be singing or mumbling anything from Charlotte in the shower


Character: 9/10


The strongest point for me. Every character has it's own trauma, it's own agenda and a nicely developed personality. The MC has a decent growth and it's not perfect, but not in the "MC is a boob obsesed guy", more likely in a "what the hell do I do with my life and superpowers?".

Every other characters has it's place and it's needed, there are no wasted characters.


Enjoyment:9/10


It's easy to enjoy, even the darkest moments let you enjoy the anime. It's not something heavy, has some messages and let you with a few questions. It's not a "Anime's over, lets grab a burguer" thing, but it won't traumatize you.


Overall: 9/10


An anime worth watching. Don't expect a memorable masterpiece, but don't expect some time filler piece of crap. It's a god series, it's a good story told in 13 episodes. It has a close ending.


I highly recommend Charlotte.

"What do you think happened to the first person who ever voiced a different opinion?" - a quote from Charlotte I found to be quite fitting.
Being a fan of Angel Beats! I was excited to hear that Jun Maeda was creating another anime original that was described as the spiritual successor to Angel Beats! I was even more happy to hear that Jun Maeda planned on fixing all the problems that plagued Angel Beats! with Charlotte.
After finishing Charlotte all I can say is their attempt at fixing Angel Beats! problems just brought a whole bunch of new problems to Charlotte. Despite my rating for Charlotteand its problems, I still actually thoroughly enjoyed Charlotte, at least for a majority of the episodes.


---Spoilers Below---


Here's a list of pros I found:

-Good concept. The idea of a world with some teens developing unique super powers really intrigued me.

-Good soundtrack. I especially like the ED: Yake Ochinai Tsubasa

-Good art and animation. As expected of P.A. Works.

-Interesting two main characters introduced at the start. (Yuu and Nao)


Cons:

-Bland side characters. They get almost no development whatsoever.

-Yuu's character development is a mess. 

-Rushed pacing. One minute everyone is playing cards, the next minute someone has been kidnapped.

-The story feels like a jumble of ideas that they tried cramming into 13 episodes.

-Deus ex Machina ending. How did they find a single lone person in China? It's never explained.

-Running jokes that are almost never funny.

-The characters have some idiotic moments just to get the plot moving. Let's approach some highly prepared terrorists that have hostages with hardly any plan at all!

-Many things left unexplained. Ever wondered why Nao is bullied? You have to read the freaking MANGA to get a vague explanation on it: http://i.imgur.com/yzNPJid.png

-Random unexplained events appearing to move the plot forward. Terrorist appearing without any foreshadowing at all?


To expand on some of the above. Yusa and Takajou have almost no importance to the story at all, we hardly learn anything about them and they don't make any large lasting impact on the story other than continuing to be friends with Yuu after everything.

This is especially obvious with Takajou since he's pretty much there as Yuu's friend and comic relief with no actual development at all. 

Speaking of character development Yuu's personality is... confusing. Despite showing signs of being quite cunning and described and introduced as a narcissist he never really shows these traits after the first episode and acts like a generic MC with a bit of snark. The only defining trait I found that sticks with him throughout the whole series is... having a sister complex.
