Today is a critique of the anime Charlotte, from the studio P.A. Works. Keep in mind that this review is mainly my opinion and in no way am I dismissing other people's view of the anime. Whether you like the anime or not is your own right, just keep that in mind so we have an understanding and respect of each other's opinions.
I'm gonna be breaking my reviews down to 3 main sections, though MAL gives you more options. I'll be talking about the art style, sound, and story.
Art Style: 8/10
The art style, from a personal perspective, is definitely pleasing. Nothing short from the sameproducers who animated Angel Beats! which is another anime I admire and is something that I will actually mention later on. There are certain scenes where they use 3D backgrounds which I found amusing though a little bit off, but hey, just my personal preference. There's not really much to marvel about the art style. Although I did say it is good, it's nothing I've not seen before. I guess you can call it traditional in this modern era of anime. That's not something to complain about though.


Sound: 7/10


Now you have to keep in mind that in no way am I a professional when it comes to criticism, especially with music. So I'm basing this off of whether or not I enjoyed it personally. Well, did I like Charlotte's music? To be honest, I'm conflicted about that. It's definitely something that struck my interest. Of course, that's probably that "new anime" vibe that it gave when I first started watching the series, but for me, the ED is really the only song I actually enjoyed when it comes to the series. An OST, in my opinion, is supposed to make you feel something special, especially in those intense or dramatic moments. I didn't really feel it with some of the songs in this anime, in fact they didn't have much impact on some scenes and sometimes I never noticed them. Again, this is just personal opinion, some people might be big on music but I only really notice them when they give huge impact on the characters or the story. (As an example, if you've watched Clannad, take a listen to the song "A Place Where Wishes Come True". You will feel the emotions right away. That's just the kind of impact it has, which a good song should do.) As for the voice acting, again, nothing special. I think there could've been times where the actors could've put more emotions into scenes, other than that, it's mediocre. I am a big fan of Kouki Uchiyama since he also voiced Raku Ichijou from Nisekoi, another anime I love.


Story: 8/10


Oh boy, here we go. Before anything else, let me ask you this; have you heard of Angel Beats? The anime about a group of supposed high school students banded together to solve their conflicts about life and supernatural events where there's this one feisty girl leader that doesn't get along with the protagonist at first? Well I basically described Charlotte AND Angel Beats. That does sound like a bad thing to some but surprisingly enough that actually kept me company. Like I said, Angel Beats is an anime I admire, and to find an anime with a similar story line is a guaranteed bonus. Of course, there are complaints. There are some elements that Angel Beats were able to deliver better than its twin and vice versa, but if an anime even remotely touches that moment where I clench my fist and make me really emotional, I won't judge it poorly. This anime made me feel sad, excited, sad, and excited again in a span of 13 episodes. A lot of plot twists and is sometimes surprisingly dark and brooding. For an anime that presents itself goofy in the beginning, I didn't expect a bunch of plot twists that are emotional. Since it only has 13 episodes however, the story line feels a bit rushed in my opinion. If given enough episodes, I think the story could've been progressed a lot better, especially the romance between the main protagonist and girl protagonist, though if the writers did not have enough material, then I can understand why. I wouldn't want fillers anyway. Still a pretty interesting story though, unless you're not a fan of a repeated story line if you've already watched Angel Beats or something similar.


Overall: 8/10


So, what's the verdict? Well, I like it, and I think you will too. I think this is something a casual fan will enjoy, though if you're really heavy on analysis, you might find a lot of flaws, but that's only if you're really nit picky. I think the best way to enjoy an anime is to forget about criticism for the first time and analyze it a second time. This anime is going to take you on a rollercoaster of emotions so if you're gonna watch it, which I recommend you do, well you better be ready for that.

*May have minor spoilers*
I feel that I'm a bit unique when I watch anime. I love pretty much any kinds of it, any genre, but I especially like the genre Drama, and love watching about the Supernatural. I heard Charlotte had a smidge of romance bundled up with it, so I decieded to watch it.
I watched all 13 episodes + OVA in one sitting. I felt that I wanted to keep watching, keep watching it. Even if Charlotte had a crappy storyline stretched over 200+ episodes, I would till waste my time bingewatching this. I rarely write reviews, but this anime, it left a permanentscar across my heart.I'll probably never forget this. I'm a big Charlotte fan, so a LOT of the reviews below may be biased. Also, this might be a late review as this review was completed over 2 years prior to the show's screening on television.


Story - 9/10

Looking around in the forums, everyone says that the final episodes are pretty rushed, and Charlotte could have been potentially extended to a 24 episode show. But I believe that although Charlotte's second half had a lot of potential to be extended or possibly a Season 2, the show was already impactful enough. The final 5 minutes of the show just broke me. The waterworks started and no matter how many times I watch the last few episodes, my heart just breaks again and again. The first half was equally enjoyable as it was comedic and funny. Overall, through Charlotte, the show just plays around with your emotions, that's why I loved the storyline.


Art 9/10

It was pretty generic, but I like the generic style. Really loved it.


Sound 9/10

The OP really did fit along with the theme of the opening video itself. I could go on Loop and watch the Opening forever. It was crafted so well, introducing the four main characters and making me realise who the other people in the opening were.


Character 9/10

Most people have different opinions on this part, but Nao was the spark for me. Her personality just, is amazing. Even though the rest of the characters were pretty generic, I really liked them and they pushed the story and made it better


Enjoyment 10/10

Tears and laughter throughout the show. What more can I say? This show strings up all sorts of emotions in you. To me, it's the show that when I think of it, my heart just starts beating. 


I would love a sequel, but it doesn't even matter if there is one or not. I'll just re-watch it again.

Alright, so I'm gonna try and make this review pretty quick.  As nearly everyone else has mentioned at this point, this is EXTREMELY similar to Angel Beats!.  That's all that I'm gonna mention about Angel Beats!, by the way.  Now, on to the show that's ACTUALLY in question, Charlotte.  The story starts off pretty uninteresting, in my opinion.  For the first five or six episodes, it was either really cool and intriguing or just plain uninteresting.  Around midseason, the show flips what you previously have come to know as Charlotte on its head and completely changes the show around.I love when shows do this.  Some great examples of shows flipping what they first show to you around would be things like Madoka Magica, Steins;Gate, RWBY, and most recently Re: Zero.  Anyways, the plot twist was genuinely interesting and I loved it, but it suffers from being extremely rushed.  This could've been a 25 or so episode series and it would've deeply benefitted from that.  So, despite the cool plot twists and interesting developments toward the latter half of the series, I have to give it a 7 for how uninterested I was for the first few episodes and how rushed the great parts of the story were.  As for the art, PA Works has done a great job with making it look good.  It may not be on the level of Madhouse or ufotable and some of their more recent shows, but it looks great.  I would say it's deserving of a 9.  It's been about 9 or 10 months since the show finished, and I cannot really recall much of the soundtrack.  I know that it did fit the scenes, but that's about all I remember.  For being a bit forgettable, I have to give it a 7.  The characters in this show were well done.  To be honest, I think this is where Charlotte shines and becomes better than that other show Jun Maeda wrote and PA Works animated (so I lied, I mentioned Angel Beats! again, after all).  Yuu was much more interesting than Otonashi, and I personally like Nao more than Yuri.  The rest of the regular characters were either fun, interesting, or both except for Yuu's little sister who was kind of "eh" for me.  She definitely added some more energy to some scenes, though, so I'll give her that.  Overall, I'd round the characters out at about an 8.  I personally really enjoyed this show.  Out of the 2015 summer anime season, I watched Gangsta, Monster Musume, Charlotte, and Prison School.  I think that it ranks at number two out of those four.  So yeah, I believe it to be well worth the watch, especially if you are a fan of Angel Beats!, because, in my opinion, it's like the better version of that (although it is 100% just as rushed).  Overall, it receives an official 8 from me.

I'll keep this short. Overall, the show has soaring peaks and deep lows in terms of quality. It starts out as nothing special, has a short span where the writing, visuals, story, drag you in and make the story as engrossing as almost any other anime I've seen. Then it's all downhill.
light spoilers ahead:
It abandons it's typical school comedy romance, which was enjoyable but nothing special, and heads in a dark direction, this being that great two episode span I mentioned above. If this were to end at episode 8 or 9 or so it would likely be one of my favorite anime. But itdoesn't. It slags onto a blown up, weird, over powered MC, drama action thriller that just felt so out of place and ruined the pace and direction of the show. \n\n
The main characters are likable and well written in my opinion, though there are some plot holes and loose ends. The character designs aren't bad, music is nothing special although with some in-show songs in English it gets and sounds off a bit.

Sometimes disappointing, sometimes beautiful and sometimes just dumb, for good or bad, Charlotte is a series of ups and downs, full of questionable decisions, plotholes and poor development in a lot of grounds, but that founds a satisfying and heartwarming way of doing its mess, it is cute, even with its lots of one dimentional characters (that kinda have a background). Overall, this anime is over-emotional but kinda loveable, just when you're really into it, because at first it just looks as the worst way of dumping the oportunity of doing a comparable series to its predecessor (Angel Beats)
Nice art and sound also, those makeit the extra point, a pleasure to watch with not a lot of attention.

Charlotte is bad ani... Nao, stop looking at me with you deep blue eyes. So, this anime had many proble... Nao, pls stop, I can't concentrate, because of yours eyes. Ok, I try this:
Charlotte - is not bad anime, but ... but there are many buts. I can't say that it is a failure, but many bad details (big and small ones) almost make it one. But there are many good things, and furthermore, it was a pleasure for me to watch this. 
==Story==
You will not be bored. There are many events in anime, the story is fast, emotional and interesting. Sometimes cool funny momenthappens, sometimes really serious drama shake the plot. One can create a nice story with this. 


We had the world where kids with super-abilities exist. For the security of this kids (and the world around) special school was created, and our heroes look for new members. Pretty good, right? Just look for one kid in one episode, then small "boss" kid in the several last episodes, and do average anime. But...


But no, the more complicated plot is needed! So add time-travel, the secret organization, and... how many episodes left? Just one... so it is enough for some world-saving. 


Because of that story become so fragmented and un-smooth. Like in one episode heroes fight secret organization, next - time travel, with minimum explanations between. Fragmentation of plot creates fragmentation of anime mood. Really tragic moments immediately is followed by funny one, then tragic again, then some dumb (but funny) scene, and then drama again. Sometimes it looks really stupid. 


About different DeusExMachina and others coincidences I will not talk much, there are plenty of this stuff, but they are ok, just ok.


==Characters==

The main hero, Yuu, maybe could be nice, but because of a fragmented story, his is fragmented too. Or maybe he is just bad. Either way, probably you will not care about him much, but in some episodes, drama is really high, that you may. 


Other characters are better, and it is because they are really simple (even if the story wants to say something else). Nao is really coldhearted all time, Ayumi and Yusa - all time moe and kawaii, and stupid friend. They are good for their roles but do not expect even little development of them. 


Relations between characters - absent. Well except Nao and Yuu, but... you probably will not believe it anyway.


==Art and music==

About Nao eyes I wrote in the beginning - they are just beautiful. And at all: art here - is almost perfect. That is why we love the 2D world. Good job.


Music also is nice, but not perfect. Both OP and ED are average, but inside of series really cool music are (especially one episode). 


==Enjoyment==

I enjoy watching this anime (I don't ask for much at all), but I suspect that there is better anime for watch, so think about it. But "Charlotte" is interesting, simple and beautiful, good for some lazy evening.

Ok, a lot of my friends talk about how they think the story of Charlotte is rushed and inconclusive. That may be true. I do agree that the grand conclusion of saving the world should've taken more than one episode. Nonetheless, I think that the rushed conclusion doesn't effect Charlotte's ability to portray a very truthful side of human nature -- the main dynamic being Yuu Otosaka. 
I believe many viewers of this anime can take away something from Yuu, who is a high school student obsessed bout nothing but his self-importance. He wants to date the cutest girl in class. In order to doso, he abuses his supernatural power of possession, an ability that allows him to possess someone else's consciousness for a few seconds, to view other people's answers during a test and get top grades to accompany his already-natural looks. As a result, he gets what he wants, but only for a short time before some cunning club members from a different school than his discover his secrets....


And then, we go through a journey of Yuu trying to change his selfish view upon the world, as he learns the meaning of gratitude before loss and gratitude after loss, as he learns the meaning of appreciation, as he learns the meaning of life apart from keeping an appearance. 


Thus, does it even matter how much time the characters spend saving the world? Even if the anime went through the process of of saving the world, does reading a story in the style of a lab procedure play any relevance in your journey to save the world? Anime inspires you to start a habit, to live up to an attitude, but not help you learn. You have to take those habits and start learning, and I think that's why Charlotte was fine with jamming the message of worldly causes

into one episode. They were fine with just leaving a reminder for the viewers to think about how to save the world, to inspire thoughts. 


Aside from my main argument, I'd really recommend this anime to anyone, because of how much life hacks it teaches you.


Appreciate the happiness you have in front of you! Do something about your problems, or regret not doing something when time has run out! Be fascinated by all the crocodiles and bananas in the world! Oh yea, dangling like monkey bars on grapevines is also fun. 


Anyways, here's to my entropic review. Cheers!

Well, yet another Jun Maeda story. I didn't realize there was so much of it xD.
I was surprised to see that many bad reviews of this anime, but I do get what people complained about. So why do I give it a good mark anyway? Because most of what we can complain about has one and only one root : the shortness of the show.
STORY
Charlotte is about an institution gathering teens who developed superpowers, in order to protect them from other groups that could use them as experimental subjects (or worse). While the concept is far from unique, the way they handle superpowers is actuallypraiseworthy: each and everyone of those "super-teens" have limited powers.

Some can't control it, others have powers with actual limitations, others are just so powerful that they have to hide it because they would be main targets otherwise.

This is a point people seem to neglect: the concept of superheroes is handled brillantly and in a unique way.


But Charlotte is also a pure Jun Maeda story: of course it starts with a club (the Student Council in this case) living their everyday life, until the story takes a dramatic turn with a lot of twists and tearful scenes.

And I think we can pretty much say... these troped have been overused. I like Maeda, but it would be nice that he tries writing something else.


The first part of the story (the Slice of Life part) totally conquered me. The comedy is silly and repetitive, but I was fine with it, and the stories this part tells are actually well thought. And of course, I won't mention episodes 6 and 7, who are definitely worth it.

The second part is where things get messy for a lot of people. This is basically a bunch of ideas taken from other shows and thrown altogether. Suddenly, the story talks about overseas terrorists trying to gather superheroes for evildoing, and somehow time travel is involved.

I did get a bit bored during this part. What it tried to tell was definitely interesting, but I really felt things were too rushed. Many characters are introduced out of the blue. Many decisions are taken out of the blue. In fact, everything happens out of the blue, because there is no time.


And because there is no time, the whole story is full of plotholes and twists that seem forced. 


Basically, Charlotte is full of brillant ideas, that are all rushed because there was simply no time to tell all of them properly.

And and this point, PA Works and the other studios should understand Maeda CAN'T tell his stories in only 13 episodes. Angel Beats had the exact same issue! Air and Little Busters Refrain also had this issue! Maeda tells wonderful stories that need TIME to build up.



ART

Charlotte is wonderful in every way. Smooth animation, wonderful light effects. I expected no less from PA Works!



SOUND

The OST didn't really appeal to me... except the opening, which I find marvelous. I do feel like the opening changes direction too much (starts as rock, keeps going as emotional, then suddenly becomes hip-hop, and gets J-Pop during the refrain...).

As for the seiyuu... I do have an issue with the main character. The dude sounded off for my ears.



CHARACTER

This is something people complained about, but frankly, I don't find the crew that catastrophic.

Tomori and Yuu are an original MC couple. For once, we have a girl who doesn't blush and acts over the top anytime love is mentioned! And frankly, that makes her character so much more believable than many other anime girls.

The same for Yuu: the fact that he is kind of a d*ck but acts friendly on the outside makes him very believable. He looks a lot like Lelouch from Code Geass (who is much, much more charismatic and clever, but Yuu was still enjoyable to follow anyway).

The rest of the characters are quite pointless for the plot, it's true. But it is justified, so I had no complain about that.



ENJOYMENT

The first part of the story is definitely worth it. The second part is rushed but is full of brillant ideas regardless. The characters and the overall show are not as deep as, say, Clannad or Kanon, but this is due to the shortness of the series.


If you can accept the fact that 13 episodes is way too short to tell a decent story, I think you can fairly enjoy Charlotte for its wonderful art and funny characters.

Personally, I did enjoy it despite the numerous plotholes and the lack of impact during most of the dramatic situations (though these can obviously be a deal-breaker).

I started this anime because a lot of people had requested me. And after Angel Beats, I was really excited because they are from the same creator. And I really liked Angel Beats so I had high hopes. I was disappointed. Really disappointed.
Characters were… To be polite, I will say it was okay. I really didn’t feel like I have a connection with these characters. They were trying to make me feel something for some character but I was like “Well, that happened.” It had a lot of different character types- at least the intention was that-  but it feels like they don’t havethe deep characteristic. They were generic characters… They didn’t have anything special about them. I mean, it feels like a lot of the characters were there just to be there. To fill the gap or to give a feeling that there is a lot of characters. And Yuu’s personality has changed at least three times in 13 episodes and it bothers me.

When I watched the first episode, Yuu was smart, manipulative, a little bit evil kind of character so I was like, “Yeah, finally some character that I would enjoy watching.” But then… He became really dull, boring, flat character. He changed fast and hard. And don’t get me started about the romance between Nao and Yuu. I don’t even want to think about it. It was inevitable because “main characters SHOULD have some kind of romantic relationship.” cliché but…It can be the most forced romance that I have seen in my life. It was cringy, it was bad. 


And the pacing of the anime... At the first episodes, it feels like it was going really slow. The story hasn’t developed yet and the reason why they gather the “special ones”, what are they fighting against was unclear. It was kind of episodic, a little bit like Angel Beats. Then it had u turn and started to rush the story. And last episodes had the speed of Usain Bolt. The story developed so quickly. The developers only continued the story just the sake of the story continuing. It was ridiculous. It didn’t make sense. And after I finished the anime, I looked back to the first episode and I didn’t recognize the anime. Yeah, the characters were the same- the appearance at least- but the story was different. Really different. I mean, you can change the characters appearance and boom. You have a new anime.


So in the end, it wasn’t good. But I guess I had really high hopes after watching Angel Beats and this anime feel like it is very flat and rushed. It was like Angel Beats but a very bad version of it. But I guess you can watch it if you don’t have any other anime to watch or you are bored and don’t know what to do. But before you watch this anime, don’t get high hopes or you will be very disappointed like me in the end.

I think this is a great, short anime that you can totally binge watch. Can be a little confusing, but stick to it and you won't regret it. The plot is a little repetitive in the beginning, but the plot twist at the end made up for it! Did not see it coming! Characters have their strengths and flaws, which makes them realistic. I think it is a very unique story, with magical powers. The people have to keep their powers a secret. This is a fantasy genre. The voice actors were fitting for the character's imagines. Overall, a great anime.

An arrogant boy has become the top student in his school. Little does the student body know he achieved this by using his secret ability taking over someone body for 5 seconds to cheat. He enjoys this supremacy in school until he encounters other ability users, and is introduced to the harsh reality of his situation. 
Charlotte is an enjoyable story that has more to it than you would think. The first half is your typical action/adventure/school life story that is entertaining enough. I was almost going to pass if off as an average story with not much unique or meaningful about it, that isuntil about halfway through there is a serious change of pace, which was an honest surprise to me.


Some of events of the latter half are some intriguing and rare moments that most anime simply don't do. The second half really changed my mind on this show, for the better. However, this didn't help the incredibly fast pace of the second half that ended up hurting the story. 


Charlotte is a decent watch, with a few great emotional moments, fun powers, and interesting story lines, but also having a many generic premises and characters that will turn many away at first. The story missing its potential and is rather cluttered and inconsistent. This anime could have been a lot better if it was given 26 episode to develop its story rather than 13.


 I still recommend giving Charlotte a shot, and personally found some enjoyment myself despite its obvious flaws. I offer that you should try reach episode 7 before dropping it if you want to experience what makes this anime worth it.

After finding out that the creator of Angel Beats was making a new anime, I was honestly excited and hyped for his new show. Angel Beats to me was a good show. Not a masterpiece, but it was good nevertheless. Which brings me to the disappointment I felt with Charlotte.
First, let's get to the positives. The art style was extremely gorgeous and fluid. The soundtrack was great. I love the opening they used. The lighthearted take on the superpower genre was also an interesting concept.  The first few episodes was a really great start for the series.  Throughout the entire series, I didfind myself enjoying it quite a bit. However, the same cannot be said for the character development and the 2nd half of the story. The 2nd half was trying just to be too much at the same time. It had too much going on and the plot twist and the ending was just too rushed. Same goes for the characters, most of which aside from the protagonist had little to no character development at all. And the limited run time does not excuse that, because they wasted earlier episodes on a bunch of unneeded filler.  The last episode had so much in it that that episode alone could have been told in three seasons worth of runtime.\n\n
Ok, I did enjoy the anime overall, but it felt lacking in many aspects, and was generally rushed. 6/10

Well, I was genuinely surprised by some of the ratings this show got as I expected it it be pretty high up there, however after reading some other reviews I believe I can understand where they are coming from. Note this is my first review. Apparently most people who had watch Angel Beats and Clannad are familiar with Jun Maeda, so they were pretty hyped for the show; however they either overhyped it and were let down or they saw too much of Angel Beats in it. Now I have never seen any of Jun Maeda's work so I just picked Charlotte up because Iwas bored. After watching the first Episode I thought it might be like Code Geass, but only with the high school setting. After watching everything I thought about the things I enjoyed and didn't enjoy.


First of all, I gave the story an 8. Overall, I liked the story it wasn't a bad one despite being a bit unoriginal; it gave me some feels here and there and some laughs. The art was nice as well, but I usually grade art based on if I'd be able to memorize any of the characters just from their silhouette and I can't do that from any character in this anime. The sound was also good and had a very good OP and ED, but it probably won't be memorable to me.



Now the one thing that drove me up the wall about this anime was how poor the character personalities were. I mean, usually there are anime character tropes like a Gothic Lolita or School Idols, but the main characters of this anime had none of that. I could not tell you what their personalities were like even after watching the entire show. For instance, when I watched first episode the main character Otosaka Yuu could probably be identified as a shrewd and cunning person but after that episode he basically becomes a pushover.


The next character is the main heroine Tomori Nao. I could not place her personality anywhere. At first I thought she might have been a tsundere, but she wasn't; next i thought she was a tomboy, but she wasn't that either. And lastly I thought she was the unexcitable straightforward type, but she wasn't that either. In the end, I honestly don't think she had a personality and it was horrible to watch. I never liked her character or attitude in the anime. 



Besides the characters I enjoyed the anime Overall and give it an 8. Honestly it might be like 7.5 barely and I understand it had only 12 episodes but if the characters had personalities and then they got some character development this show could have easily been a 10 in my book.


So should you watch Charlotte? Well, I guess it's okay if you want to pass the time, but I don't think it's something I'd recommend to friends.

SHITTY REVIEW
-shamelessly presents-
Charlotte
**SPOILER FREE**
Charlotte was the only anime last season while being on air.
So after seeing one trailer I thought this would  an action adventure.But It turn out to be completely different.While I enjoyed the first half  I also enjoyed the second half at the same level but with completely different feelings.Why it is so this review will try to explain that.

- REVIEW -
1. ART & ANIMATION
The character designs are like your typical Key show, some look ok, others look generic, but to be honest the character designs look like a bland Angel Beats re-hash/palette swap. Artistic background and designs are amazing, as expected from P.A WORKS everything is touched upon from the smallest details and feels lively and colorful... Never a dull moment when they do their backgrounds.
Animation-wise the show lacks it in later episodes where time just stands still most of the time and characters seem to sit in stone talking for a decade while the episode just flows until it ends. It feelssloppy at times, but at some others it looks good. But overall the characters distract you from paying much attention to the animation errors so you probably won't notice them.\n\n
2. SOUND\n
The soundtrack in Charlotte is great, like all Key shows, but of course. SAD MUSIC DOES NOT MAKE THE SHOW ANY BETTER THAN IT SHOULD BE! Just because it made you cry.\n
It has a certain charm to it that it'll never get tiresome if you're a fan of relaxing tunes and insert songs. OP & ED's are great aswell, it just proves to show how Maeda knows how to handle his audience when it comes to music.\n\n
3. STORY & CHARACTERS\n
Jun Maeda is known for making the script of most if not all key shows, and just proves how lously he does it, it focuses more on the moment when you're suppose to feel bad or cry and not developing the actual characters to make you feel like they are a part of the cast. In most cases they feel like wooden planks who cry for the sake of depression, and that he has no idea what character drama or how a character could be written without feeling like a plot device.\n
The directing is somewhat better because Maeda isn't directing it, but that isn't saying much. There is almost no tension because it gets killed by a predictable outcome, character interaction feels like they are loafs to be loafs so people can laugh along side them.\n
STORY-wise the show lacks any decent outcome and through the most basic things it's as predictable as ever, and like every key production it ends with an overblown ending that either, makes the viewer facepalm from stupidity asking why? Or making them cry a river just because the song was sad. Or these blobs got sad because someone died, the story lost its tension and interest after the first episode. It wasn't surprising it was just over blown for the sake of making ISFP's or people who like goofy characters because they could relate to them.\n\n
4. PRODUCTION VALUES & ENJOYMENT\n
Production values are great, yes they are that good. Detailed put alot of work and heart put in All key shows look great and sound great but that's all.\n
Enjoyment-wise unless you're a fan of stupid things and goofy comedy or a crybaby this is for you, for me this is boring, uninspired, dull and boring.

Watching Charlotte,  I expected great things from a Key anime, and all I can say is that it was ok. It wasn't too good, but it definitely wasn't bad. Charlotte is an anime about superpower-bearing teenagers; now that sounds familiar. 
In terms of storyline, there are a number of plot holes that, if noticed, can ruin quite a bit of the anime. I won't point out any for the sake of spoilers, but it should be clear enough once you watch it. Although most of these plot holes have plausible explanations, it feels wrong to know that something happened without you knowing. Other thanthe plot holes, the storyline was good and unexpected to say the least. There were just enough twists and turns to keep someone interested. Romantic development between the characters is a kind of romance that isn't easily felt. It's more of a deep kind of caring rather than just a random highschool crush.


In terms of characters, they could have done better. Each of the characters was remarkably well defined, but none of them really showed major character development aside from Yu and Misa. 


Art-wise,  Charlotte is juuust avove average; it has cute but sensible graphics. Other than that, there isn't much to say.


Sounds. Bravely You is definitely one of my favorite openings, as it makes sense only when youre near the end of the anime, and the melody is good overall. The ending wasn't as good in my opinion, and the background music went mostly unnoticeable.


Overall Charlotte is a good anime to add to your list. It isn't terribly good but it can give you a few good hours of anime. I'd recommend this to anyone who is particularly fond of the high school setting.

Well, we've finally "got home." It's been a good run, folks; 13 episodes of ups, downs, Key Magic™, and Maeda Feels. After watching, and in some cases rewatching, the entirety of this show, I can say, without reservation:
FAILURE OF THE SEASON CON-BLASTED-FIRMED.
This review will be structured into an unspoilered section with overall impressions, followed by a link to an archive of the midseason review along with some spoilery opinions. The linked document has FULL SEASON SPOILERS, so read at your own risk.
===================================================
//The Quick and Dirty//
Charlotte is a profound disappointment. Its story begins promisingly before alternating between mundane filler, nonsensical twists, and Angel Beats "oh crapwe only have 3 episodes left" syndrome. Its characters begin promisingly, but soon delve into forced archetypes to fit the checkboxes on a "Jun Maeda Feels Trip" roster, with pointless interactions given entire episodes and with meaningful ones abandoned at the drop of a hat.


Charlotte is Angel Beats 2.0, and not in a good way - it did everything Angel Beats did wrong, and nothing that Angel Beats did right. It promises the world - deep characters, feels-jerking twists, and a grand story - and delivers nothing.


I wish it was better. I honestly wish I could praise this show like it was the masterpiece it had the potential to be - but to do so would be lying. 


===================================================


//STORY - 2 [9]//

At its core, the plot of Charlotte is a solid one. It offers an interesting angle on the industry-standard "highschoolers with superpowers" premise by throwing in a bit of reality: What would a *real* highschooler with body possession do? Go save the world from evil alien invaders? No, he'd use it to peek at girls' boobs, cheat on tests, and generally be the brat teenagers tend to be. Power corrupts, absolute power corrupts absolutely, and absolute power in the hands of hormone-addled children is terrifying. Into this core theme we throw the plot hook - Lelouch, er, Yuu gets caught by some goody-two-shoes ability wielders who use their powers for GOOD, to protect those with powers from the mysterious, evil, all-powerful scientists that would sooner vivisect you than give a damn about basic human rights. 


That's episode 2. It's all downhill from there.


The plot of Charlotte is disjoint, and that's being generous. If I *wasn't* generous, I'd say the plot of Charlotte is as rushed and disjoint as one of my infamous "I have two hours to write 10 pages on a topic I know nothing about" papers. Those papers are shit, and Charlotte's plot is worse, veering from one theme to another and jumping between arcs without a trace of narrative transition. 


There are a LOT of good story ideas. The student council's quest to find and warn others from abusing their powers. Yuu's emotional struggles. The ending arc alone could very well be the basis for an entire anime in and of itself. The problem is, none of these ideas are given an appropriate measure of time - the first few episodes of Charlotte feel slow and repetitive before it realizes "Oh, I have 6 episodes left to tell the rest of the story."


Charlotte wants to have the character investment of a Slice of Life, the spectacle of an Action show, and the suspense of a Drama. However, these elements are neither balanced nor executed properly. Several episodes are absolutely WASTED on boring, poorly written SoL-esque episodes, where the obvious intent is to build rapport with our characters before ripping your heart out, and later episodes don't give their elements enough time or detail to be effective. Story elements that should have been half a cour long are compressed into a single episode, and story elements that should've been 5 minutes of the pilot episodes take five episodes. 


What strong story moments there were, Charlotte wasted. There are moments within Charlotte that I have previously described as being "The biggest waste of emotional capital since Aldnoah Zero S2," though unfortunately describing them would be spoilers. So, imagine a show where the Episode 6 twist is that the pre-OP scene is the MC's house burning down. The OP plays, and the next scene is a continuation of a battle scene from the previous episode, and the whole "Your home, possessions, and immediate family all burned to a crisp before your eyes" is never mentioned again. THAT'S the kind of waste Charlotte commits over, and over, and OVER.


Charlotte had the POTENTIAL to be a 10/10 story. However, and yes this is a buzzword, ABYSMAL pacing dropped that all the way down to a 2, salvaged only by the quality of what good storytelling there was. 


===================================================


//Art - 8//

There's little argument that Key Visual Arts and PA Works are among the best studios around when it comes to sheer quality of animation and character design. I've little to really say here besides "It looks fantastic" - animation is consistently top-tier, even when other elements of the show faltered. I salute thee, animators of Charlotte, for maintaining quality of work even whilst your writers and directors did fuck all.


I would, however, like to point out that Charlotte's OP is my undisputed BEST OP OF THE SEASON. There's more to animation than making the drawings look good - there's stylistic choices, framing, and raw imagination that makes a well-drawn picture into an amazing animation. Charlotte's OP is prime example of that. Words alone can't do it justice - just watch it. Even if you don't want to watch the whole show, watch the OP - it's just that good.


I do have to knock off points for a few egregious technical mistakes, at times, which can largely be attributed to piss-poor storyboarding; it's notsomuch the animators' fault for animating poorly as it is the producer's fault for ordering them to animate a shitty scene. As I just mentioned, there's more to animation than pretty pictures; cinematography, the art of framing camera angles and effects, is an art unto itself that requires considerable attention. There are several times where, in order to accommodate extra dialogue or to stretch out a scene, the camerawork is flat out SHIT. There's one instance of a camera shot from the perspective of something falling onto someone (no spoilers: it could be a girl falling onto our MC in a classic comedy setup, it could be a meteor sent by the hand of god to smite some side character for drama). This camera angle is *very* common in both animation and live action. You quickly pan into the victim's face just long enough to register the look of surprise, then cut - whether it's to a humorous scene of the standard "MC groping heroine's breast" shot or a display of blood and gore that'd make Tokyo Ghoul cringe. In this scene, however, it lingers - it cuts to a pan of a closeup, rather than cutting away. It was one of the most disorienting moments I've ever experienced just from watching anime, so much so that I STILL am ticked off by how bad it was weeks after the fact.


===================================================


//Sound - 8//

As is a specialty of Jun Maeda and Key Visual works, Charlotte uses music from its pet band, with an obligatory concert scene to boot. The soundtrack is, save for the OP and ED, largely forgettable. Application of music to scene is hit or miss, with some scenes having very well matched music and some scenes feeling totally disjoint. 


The voice acting, however, deserves praise. With a mix of veteran and newcomer seiyu, the vocal performances manage to carry through, even when required to deliver some really crappy lines. Of particular note, a shoutout to Uchiyama Kouki for his performance on Yuu, with a fantastic range of emotional delivery; and to the VAs who delivered the English lines in a certain later episode. Save one, that was some TOP NOTCH English impersonation - for once, it actually sounded like English, rather than a Japanese person reciting English words. Heck, the worst lines in that episode are actually the fault of what (as far as I can tell) is an *American* VA.


===================================================


//Character - 5 [8]//

As collateral damage of the show's abysmal plot pacing, the character development of the cast suffers immensely. To start off with, we have some very well designed and intriguing characters, who are archetypical in some aspects but with enough unique aspects to be interesting. However, as the show progresses, so-called "character development" reveals flatter and flatter personalities in all but Yuu's case (who has his own problems). For instance, Joujirou, who at the start has a good hold on a comedic character element with his own quirks, is quickly relegated into a purely gag role, and an unfunny one at that, before fading from the show entirely - he stops being relevant a few episodes in, and then he turns up in a later episode being treated like he's somehow just as important and developed as our MC. What character development there IS for the cast is either ineffectual or counterproductive - the episodes devoted to Slice-of-Life esque interactions offer no lasting developments. What's worse, the show pretends like it's being totally effective in building up a connection between the viewer and characters, and because of this assumption a lot of moments in the show have absolutely no impact - "So, this guy's sad for some reason, why, and why should I care?"


Yuu is a whole different demon when it comes to HIS character. Yuu has an odd mix of being intriguing one minute to being more passive than a harem protagonist the next. He only seems to act in-character as the plot demands - something bad just happened, so Yuu must be angsty! Something weird just happened, so Yuu must be confused! Several elements of his progression of his character come from nowhere, and others are gone like the drop of a hat. There is one episode that deals with certain psychological trauma Yuu endures - ONE episode. He experiences trauma, he has a depressive period, then he's redeemed by the power of friendship and it's NEVER MENTIONED AGAIN. Y'know how, in Pokemon, Ash goes through all these adventures and hardships yet still reacts to every experience like he's fresh out of Pallet Town? That's Yuu's character development. 


Charlotte, again, has GREAT character design, but utterly wastes that potential with sloppy storytelling and sloppy character interactions. 


===================================================


//Enjoyment - 7//

To be honest, in the long game I enjoyed Charlotte. I don't finish anime that I don't enjoy in some way, shape, or form (looking at *you,* Glasslip). For all its flaws, Charlotte does manage to be entertaining from episode to episode. It bears testament to what the show COULD'VE been that the elements of the good that managed to shine through were enough to carry me through the entire show. 


===================================================


//Overall - 4//

Charlotte is Angel Beats 2.0: doing everything Angel Beats did wrong, and none of what it did right.


In a way, I almost imagine Charlotte as being the product of Jun Maeda sitting down and asking "What did people like about Angel Beats? I'll just do those things, and make them even BIGGER, which will make it better." The influence is obvious - we have the (attempt) at building rapport with interesting, human characters, we have a midseason tearjerker that changes everything, we have a blossoming love between two complementary souls that's tensely built before reaching a heartwarming confession. Everything about Charlotte is tangibly formulaic - this scene is meant to make you laugh and like this character; this scene is meant to show this character's secret weaknesses to make you sympathize with them; this scene is meant to TEAR YOUR SOUL OUT. Jun Maeda's formula worked in his previous stories to varying degrees - Clannad, Little Busters, and Gunslinger Girl all spring to mind as examples where it was wildly effective.


Charlotte checks all the boxes and fits all the requirements of what, historically, should be another masterpiece from Jun Maeda. However, good fiction, almost by definition, CANNOT be a checklist - in meeting all of those requirements, Charlotte ceased to be an organic story and became a mechanical slog. Characters were left to waste, because they'd done their job in ticking off the "genki girl" or "stoic heroine" requirements. Fantastic plot hooks were left unused, since once they completed the "dark and troubled past" mark they were discarded like throwaway gags. 


It's disappointing. Charlotte should, by all respects, have been a masterwork. All the elements were there - talent, ideas, resources. But just having all the parts available doesn't mean you'll assemble it right - and Charlotte, be it through hubris, negligence, or honest screwups, is broken even beyond the capacity of Key Magic to repair.


===================================================

I'm stumbled Charlotte long time ago, but only watched it until yesterday. At first I was reluctant because of lots of negative review about it but as the saying says A man's trash is another man's treasure so I give it a shot
Story = 8
The story is simple and straight forward. It's about people in his/her puberty period who develops special powers, though these powers will be gone the time you finished your puberty, There's nothing new about that, there is other anime have similar plot where the setting is school with superpowers. However I'm not viewing Charlottte on that. I'm viewing it on thevalues and lessons its sharing. It is kinda subtle but there are things in life you can learn with Charlottte . I guarantee you that.


Art = 9

The art is refreshingly good, the animation gives this refreshing and light feeling about it. I personally prefer that style because it feels like you can be engulf on the setting itself. That's the feeling I getting from it.


Sound = 9

From the Background music, opening song, ending song and even insert song it never manage to disappoint me. I love how the sound fits on the anime and how spot in the timing when they pull it off together with the scene. Ahh.. The voice acting is superb too that I can get enough of Tomori and Misa's voice in my head.


Character = 7

I've read in another review that the characters are "shallow" though I'm not going to argue with others because its their preferences but for me it's not the case. Sure they don't fill us with any more information about the characters but that kinda give Charlotte the atmosphere it needs to be unique. I mean that triggered my curiosity at them and made me crave for the next episode. So I'm saying this they are not shallow but the opposite, they are much more than what they are. If you take time to analyze them you'll see what I mean. I hate getting character development when the anime just push the spoon on our palate, and that's not Charlotte do so that's why I like it.


Enjoyment and Overall = 9

Ahh I can't believe how late I was to watch this anime.  Charlottte is one of those anime that when I remember, it makes my heart flutter and put a smile on my face. If you're fond of something light but can be heavy at the times it needs to be then Charlotte is spot on for you. What can I just say as a piece of advice is, "Observe and just enjoy it. Don't think about it's negative review just sit down and try to feel the anime."


Then if you are still reading then Thank you and Have a nice time in watching!

This anime is about this good looking teenager called Yuu Otosaka who happened to have supernatural powers. He misused his powers and as a result he had to join a group of teenagers (led by Nao Tomori) to find those who use their super powers wrongly. And save them before scientists find them and experiment them.
Story (10)
Anyways, the story itself was changing its direction with every episode. Although, the first few episodes were fairly the same idea but then it started getting more serious. Yet, still important for the story to actually go through all these changes to give the ending its meaning. One thingkept on happening from the beginning which is… THE EXCITEMENT! I enjoyed this anime so much! They never failed in surprising me or making me cry or even laugh. It was super well made! The first thing I said to describe this show to my friend was “I haven’t been feeling this much excitement in too long.”


Cons? Well…… I think its great but if the last 3 episodes weren’t too packed with stuff it would’ve been better. Like.. the last 3 episodes did what you would like to see in a whole season.. not even exaggerating. By the 12th episode I thought its the ending. Right there. Until I realized there is one more episode to go. It wasn’t horrible but I would’ve loved more details and emotions……. and tears.



Character (4)

Characters, ugh too many characters in this anime which makes it hard for some main characters to actually develop. Lets just focus on the development of the main characters.

Nao and Misa had minor changes in their personalities by the end. While a mine character like Takajou was the same from the beginning. He actually didn’t have so much to do unfortunately. Yusa wasn’t really a useless main character but she wouldn’t be that important if not for Misa (Her sister). Ayumi (Yuu’s sister) was very important for the story but she didn’t get so much focus and her development was too small that you can even ignore it. Yuu, on the other hand, who is the main protagonist, was really shifting personalities and went from bad to good to better to worst to terrible to everything! He suffered the most, I’d say. The story was focused a lot on Yuu and Nao to the point where even more important characters to the story didn’t get much to do. Weird?  Yes but I really was able to love every single character because each got to show what makes them lovable. You might think that this anime is full of cliché characters but well… at least you’ll enjoy the story cuz its an enjoyable cliché to some extent.


Shout out to Jun Maeda, creator of Angel Beats and Clannad. Who also happen to be the creator of Charlotte, and all our tears, broken hearts and laughters. 

Jun Maeda, Whats good?



Art (10)

Animation?  Exactly as if you’re watching Angle Beats (Thats why I brought it up lol). If you never watched it, then go what are you waiting for? 

Charlotte had an amazing, amazing, AMAZING animation! I loved the colors, the eyes, the skies (it rhymes). It also had an amazing opening and closing that I don’t skip not for the music but only to enjoy the art. You see the 2015 advanced animation.



Soundtrack (10)

It was really beautiful. I didn’t really like the opening and closing but THEY WERE NOT BAD. They were fair. I just have a weird music taste. But honestly the background music did a great job making me enjoy every and each emotion that the story made me feel. It was perfectly  composed to fit right there. To be honest, the story, animation and music were all in harmony.. a beautiful rhythm.


Enjoyment (10)

LOVED IT!!! But I have to mention.. some episodes might really hurt your soul.. You might feel a hole in your heart for some time. imagine I had to feel the pain for a whole week untill the next episode is out.. you guys (who haven’t watched it while it was airing) are lucky lol. Enjoy it and please let me know what you think about it.



Overall (9)

All in all, Charlotte was a great anime. Not suitable for everyone. yet, really entertaining. Yes has clichés but it was perfectly hidden till you actually take time to analyze it. (I didn’t realize till I started writing, honestly. although I am known to be a cliché alert person.) The amazing scenes and all the ups and downs were just amazingly put together.

Well, i dint expect anything when i added this series to my list this season, nor was i aware it was from the studio that brought us clannad. At first i thought it was a high school comedy, and while it has its moment, with time it hits with a sudden rise in plot development, where tension and mystery to the point that it hooks you up ot the point that you cant wait for the next chapter. Indeed i was surprised and i must say that this series has its hidden gem that can be seen upon its initial superficial look. Its a seriesthat slowly wraps you up with its slow well done development. Sure it there are a lot lighthearted funny moments, but there is also a ton serious moments that make the plot move at the right moments, without leavng plot holes in the midst. 

In the end i do recommend this series as it feels like a real slice of life, it has school drama( bit cliche but its kept to a minimum) with pieces of supernatural phenomenons, which make the series all the better.


Story: I t develops well, and when it has to. There are no plot holes as the plot moves slowly while explaining everything, which means that patience is required, as it wont give you everything from the get go. In the end this series is everything you don't expect as it tends to get serious really fast, and cliffhangers appear, as it is a series as hole and not a bunch small arcs. 


Art: Awesome, at times cute, but why expect anything else, when its Aniplex and PA WORKS the ones that are involved, and they never fail at delivering high quality entertainment. 


Sound: Again Aniplex is involved, so of course it is good. 


Characters: Well the developments of the character is well balance, like i said before, this is a series that develops at balanced precise pace. Bits of information for each character are given at their own time in ways that are not to obvious, and it was that does not get in the way of the story development, as it wont stop progression just to show you a hole episode of a characters past, Besides it's a 13 episode series so they cant afford to do that, since plot is primordial. Like i said this producers are making this series in a very smart way.


Enjoyment: well i love mystery as of recently, and i have always been a fan of slice of life series, as they tend to give simple yet fun stories. And if plot twists are right in your alley that this series will do you good.


Overall. It is a fun series, and is worth watching. I cant give it a perfect score as the series is not without flaws, but in many ways it makes up for  its flaws by providing a main character, that evolves really well toward the end. 


Its a 8.5 in my books

This is my first review so go easy on me ;)
So, where do we start? Charlotte, the first time I saw this anime on MAL and read the synopsis I thought to myself "ok, this one is definitely worth watching. It probably will have a fair amount of drama and deal with serious issues regarding the plot elements". However, after watching the first few episodes, I saw that I was completely mistaken. The anime had a slice of life feel to it, and many episodes ( Like the baseball game or the hunt after a random ability wielder) didn't give the story a big push.And then suddenly episode 6 came, there was a huge shift in the story progression, where a lot of things happened in a single episode and sometimes you were left wondering why did they include filler episodes when they wanted to deal with such stories and drama? I felt it was rushed. New characters were introduced but none of them (except maybe one I'm not going to name for spoiler reasons) had a decent amount of character development. They could've either gone with a complete slice of life/comedy story or started the anime from the beginning concentrated on the drama and the serious parts of the story. They also could've gone with a second season/2-cour anime, but the way the last 2-3 episodes were rushed, It's very unlikely. That's why I gave the story a fair 6, It had A LOT of potential, but in my opinion, a large chunk of it was wasted. \n
The art was great. The combination of a great usage of various colours and a good drawing style created a great anime in terms of art style. Most of the characters were drawn beautifully and I couldn't find anything wrong with the art or the drawing style.\n
The music and songs were great too, they made a wonderful use of the music, especially the timing. One example would be episode 13. I just felt really drawn in by the music of this anime.\n
Character development is another section I found some errors with. Some characters were not given much time to shine, others came and went as they pleased, with one character being completely absent from a few episodes. The main characters had decent development in my mind and I found myself liking their personalities. \n
Overall, I enjoyed the anime, but I can't help thinking how much of a better show this could've been. Still, I recommend you to watch It because overall, this is a good show.

The sound and music of this Anime far outweighs all that I have ever watched. 
Very well picked soundtracks.
I stopped the anime just to play it on guitar. I'm serious, it was just that good.

We could have had it all, Charlotte.
This series started off great. I enjoyed it a lot and for the direction it was going for. I assume I don't need to tell you what it was about, but it was going great for the first half. I didn't mind the episodic format that it took to get us settled into the world of Charlotte. If you're reading this among the many Charlotte reviews already, then you must already know that the second half did not do any justice to the second. 
Way too rushed, way too many things going on -- there are just a lotof factors that lead to it being a disappointment, at least for me. There were interesting characters all throughout the series. Some, if not most, get the unfair shove to give others more screentime (people who don't like moe or idol-like characters, I guess you should stay away from this show). The art was beautiful, too, and the seiyuus were pretty top-notch. I'm not familiar with the creator's previous work (Clannad? Yeah, I tried but not my cup of tea) but he sounds like someone who knows how to do his job. So in theory, everything should be able to work, right?\n\n
Nope. Somehow, I feel like it had all these elements going for it but it just didn't play out well. Maybe it's the 13-episode format? It had major pacing issues. Charlotte will inevitably turn up in various discussions in anime, I believe. So I will stop this rant-filled review from there.\n\n
At the end of the day, would I recommend this title to anyone else? Yes, if you're into stories of teenagers with extraordinary super powers and anti-heroes in general. It's quite a ride and despite its many MANY flaws, I enjoyed watching it as  well. (I seriously got angry at some parts but that's all part of the ride.) I would not recommend this if you're looking for something with tighter and much more coherent storytelling and arguably something much more substantial or if you're just looking for something mindless to watch. It's quite polarizing in a way.

Who knew that something simple would turn into something big...
When I first saw Charlotte, I thought it'd be another coming-of-age anime with a mediocre protagonist and some other flat characters. I was flat out wrong. And here's why:
_____________________________________________________
Firstly, the characters were more round and dynamic, especially Otosaka Yuu. From a cheater to an OP superhero, that's not something you see everyday. Also, he showed how we humans can also turn bad when aware of our capabilities. Fortunately, he didn't end up evil because he had his resolve. He is definitely a character that we can all relate to, even though we don't have his ability.
Othercharacters were well-rounded as well, such as Nao, Yuu's brother, etc. They were really given detailed personality, as if they were real people. If there's one thing that caught my eye, it was this. Good job, Jun Maeda!\n
_____________________________________________________\n
Next, we have the art style. PA works really outdid themselves. It was just as good as KyoAni, if I do say so myself. The background looked so realistic and detailed to the last spot (except some small exceptions).\n
_____________________________________________________\n
The story was good, although it had flaws here and there. I could see so many plot holes in some episodes (naming them would be spoilers) but other than that, it went well. The flow of the story was quite different from other anime in a way that each episode can stand on its own while still preserving continuity of the plot.\n
_____________________________________________________\n
Overall, I loved Charlotte. If I could, I would give it an award. It really is a great series. I recommend it to all those who want something different and unique.

Well this is my first time writting a formal review of an anime online as i usually done it on facebook or any other related social websites. So back into business. The anime Charlotte is one of the newly released animes that was being released as a summer 2015 anime and it has a total of 13 episodes. The story tells us about a young boy who develops superhuman abillities which he used it for his general purposes until he met another group of people who also posessed those special abillities too and that is when the storybegins. Thus,they are many aspects that i want to stress and to make you comprehend completely about this anime.


Firstly,is about the storyline. To be honest,the whole plot is mainly about the characters' depressing and painful life stories as they continue with their lives along with their superhuman abillities. The episodes are fit together neatly into a continuous story but if we talk about the ending,it is way too rush.There are whole lots of unexplained things and questions and they are plot holes too that is supposed to be explained in the next season but i dont think that will happen. However,the story is actually pretty interesting and unique too but the suspense after one episode ends is really huge. Also,some of the comedies made by the characters can sometimes be funny and hilarious. Most crucially,every episode will harbour tons of feelings and sadness. 


     Secondly,the artstyle is simply a masterpiece. I mean just look at the graphics of the sceneries and even the characters,are quite marvelous! to be honest,the first time i watched the first episode i was really flabbergasted by its flawless graphics and this makes the anime,the story and the characters well suited. When in terms of the characters' designs, i sometimes find them not that appealing as some of them had really huge eyes and sometimes the nosebleed of Ayumu isnt necessary in the anime. Overall, their appearance did match their personalities and attitudes.


Furthermore,all I can say that the opening and ending songs are really superb! they really fit well with the atmosphere and the storyline of the anime and as well as the characters. You got this fantasy feeling as you are listening to these songs in a fantasy realm. Next is the seiyuus. Well some of them really fits the character like Nao with her light-kuudere but deep voice (I dont know how to describe it). There is this band called ZHIEND which Nao really likes and i am surpised that they also made outstanding music and as a result, i really love their music!


  To make a review about the characters,I will start with the worst and the best. The first is Ayumi Otosaka. After her first tribute in the early episodes,I already cant tolerate her extreme" loliness" personality,her overused "desu" words and most obviously,her nosebleeds but im glad that it was over before i knew it. Next are the protagonists and Im going to start with Yuu Otosaka. His personalites had a lot of negatives like using his power to cheat in exams,doesnt wanted to listen to other's opinions and the like in the first early episodes but as he met Nao,the Student President Council,he gained a lot of things and before he knew it,he had done of of the most generous and heroic attributes in his life. The minor characters arent that many but some of them did play their own roles like the mysterious girl who wanted to kill Ayumi. The narrators are the characters themselves but only appeared at the first and the end of the series if im not mistaken.


To conclude,Charlotte is an interesting and delightful anime as it upholds the depressing moments and flashbacks of the characters like losing someone you love, protecting your family members by any means and being kidapped as lab mice for greedy needs. Personally i really enjoyed this anime as the genre of the anime are supernatural and fantasy and those are the things that are compulsory in any anime that i watched although not every single one of them. In my opinion some of the people will dislike this anime because of the major flaws but at the same time Charotte can teach you lots of valuable lessons and moral values. If you like tragic and sad moments,not to mention supernatural related things, this anime is for you.

Nothing gets me more excited than new content from KEY. That being said, when I heard about Charlotte, my emotions ran wild and my happiness-meter went through the roof (Which sucks because I had to buy a new one). What excruciatingly sad, yet sometimes obnoxiously joyous story could they have in store for me this time around? Will Lia sing the opening song again? What lessons are there to be learned? And more importantly, what adorable girls has Na-ga Rindou drawn for us this time around? Well, suffice it to say, all of those things happened. But this time, they felt a little different. NowI am forced to decide just how different and whether that difference is good or not.


Charlotte is brought to us straight from the mind of none other than Jun Maeda. It is directed by the talented Yoshiyuki Asai, which explains a lot considering this show felt almost identical to Angel Beats! The cast was impressive as well, bringing us names like: Maaya Uchida, Ayana Sakura, and Kouki Uchiyama. Right off the bat, we have tons of elements that should be able to, even by themselves, make an anime extremely enjoyable with a hint of familiarity. And if reviewing came down to literally just that, Charlotte would have been a perfect success. But there are some holes that the all-star cast and staff couldn't fill. The biggest of these holes being the one that was left by the overall length of the show, finishing at just 13 episodes.


The star of this anime (Even though I wanted it to be the wonderful Nao Tomori so, so much) was the narcissistic and broody Yuu Otosaka. Just like in most KEY stories, there is phenomenal character development. There's just one problem -- all of that development was used on Yuu. And it worked, don't get me wrong. I think he is one of the greatest KEY creations so far. He felt real and went from extremely unlikable to totally likable and then back to unlikable all over the course of the short series. Even though that seems sporadic and odd on paper, it was great. You really got a feel for who he was and how easy it was for traumatic experiences to shape him into a new person. But everyone else was kind of static for the most part. The list of characters were great in every way apart from their development. Design was flawless, dialogue was high-tier, and the acting was spot on. That just once again reinforces what I said from earlier about too much time being used on Yuu. If viewers had just a little more time to get to know what was behind the rest of the characters, this could have been spectacular. Even Nao, who is essentially the second main character, has almost nothing revealed about her past. She just kind of mentions it in passing and then shrugs it off. That isn't the way KEY normally goes about something like this. And you can say that can be attributed to her cold, disinterested character, but that doesn't satisfy me. It just makes it harder to care. (But I still do just because she's so pretty, oh my god).


As for the story, we have something here that I believe could have been in the top three for KEY, had it been done the way I (And so many others) thought it should be done. That once again brings us to the controversial issue of series-length. This isn't your average anime story, folks. We have a main character who joins a sort of witness protection program for adolescent superheroes, has to deal with a traumatic, life-changing event and falls into an untimely despair, GOES BACK IN TIME, fights off terrorists, and SAVES THE WORLD all in just 13 episodes. The first four or so of them were exposition, by the way. It's a general rule of thumb that saving the world needs more than one episode. So why did KEY execute the final arc of Charlotte in this manner?


I'm going to dedicate this whole paragraph to the Yuu x Nao relationship, but specifically what happens in the last few episodes, starting with his confession to her. That is the one thing that I feel was executed perfectly in terms of them as a couple. It's evident in the last few episodes that Yuu is coming to terms with his feelings for Nao. Hell, it becomes evident as soon as she appears and saves him from further harming himself during his gangster-esque fallout halfway through the season. And her reaction to his confession? Priceless and spot on. She reacts exactly how you would imagine her reacting, and that tightens your heart-strings to maximum extension. From that point on though, it starts sloping downward, yet still containing that tinge of curiosity and hope the audience is clinging to, the same way that Yuu is clinging onto his flash-cards from Nao -- even when he forgets how he got them. It's just...his whole journey thing happens in a 20 minute period and he forgets all about her within that time. Had that been stretched out over several episodes and had his memory started slipping away little by little, it would have created an extremely depressing turn of events that would normally be synonymous with KEY work. In the end, their reunion is equal parts miserable and happy. I just wanted more than the brief moments of semi-love that I got to experience.


Even though the plot was convoluted and the pacing was a bit "All over the place," I think Charlotte still hits hard. Just not as hard as it was supposed to. The tonal shifts, though some people have a problem with them, create a way for viewers to become more attached to the characters over a short period of time. Those lighthearted moments that shape the bulk of the episodes quickly turn sour at the drop of a hat, and instead morph into something that winds up causing your jaw to drop. However, the pacing of this show in particular sometimes accelerates those moments and instead creates more of a confusing effect. A lot of the time, I was uncertain how to feel. But there were still elements that were extremely above-average. One of those being the use of vision.


Think back to the characters that were blind -- Sala Shane of ZHIEND, Shunsuke Otosaka, and eventually half of Yuu. What Sala and Shunsuke have in common is that both of them, despite being unable to see, somehow manage to see more than anyone. Those two could easily be considered the wisest out of the entire cast in terms of doing exactly what they need to do at all times -- and not just for themselves, but for everyone. Yuu, on the other hand, loses one eye (Obviously resulting in losing half of his vision). This could wind up being a metaphor for how torn up his personality became. Even though he knew what he must do, there was that level of uncertainty and hesitance that kept dragging him down. In my opinion, that was one of the best uses of symbolism that I have seen from KEY.


In Summary:

Charlotte isn't your typical anime. It has a lot to say, but doesn't have time to say it. It is yet another perfect example of how length of a story versus airtime can cause even the most skilled of writers to rush certain aspects. There are elements of Charlotte that far surpass other anime out there. There aren't, however, many elements that surpass the ever-expanding portfolio from KEY. The high standards they set for themselves wound up unfortunately causing this show to be a step or two under their average. Does that make it bad? Not a chance. Charlotte is still one of the most hard-hitting shows of the year and brings viewers a warm, nostalgic feeling through ambient, emotional music and a sentimental color palate. I'd recommend this to anyone.

Charlotte is a mixture of supernatural, drama, comedy and a little bit of slice of life anime original written by Jun Maeda, the man who innovated the "will make you cry" or in other words the 'Nakige' genre with his Visual Novels like Kanon, Clannad, Little Busters and production by P.A Works, the studio behind the beautifully animated Nagi no Asakura and Angel Beats.
Story: The Premise And The Positive.
Charlotte started promising with how the story was presented. The concept of the story is kind of like from Marvel comics where superheroes need to hold responsible of their powers but with a little twist, our maincast are on a mission to convince other teenagers with powers to never use them until they reach adulthood where their powers will just vanish. Why are they doing that? Well just like any other story with super powers, there are scientists who will do inhuman experiments on you when they find out you're a freak.


While the premise is kind of typical from a westerner's point of view, it still manage to be different as their powers has some kind of limit. Like the main protagonist, Yuu has the power of taking over other people's body but it will only take affect in 5 seconds. With the limitations, the characters are doing what they can to use their powers cleverly and with the help of one another they always manage to accomplish their goal.


Everything is relaxed and episodic in the first half of the series. Each episode was about searching for teenagers with powers and convince them to not use their power again through either blackmail or beating them to their own game (like a baseball player with powers, the main cast will compete with him with a game of baseball). Surprisingly, they are always successful. I kind of question of how they convince these people will even work if it happens in real life. But hey this is anime we are talking here. Still, seeing the group collaborate using their powers without exaggerated violence, and replacing it with a funny event is kind of amusing.



Story: The Negative.


Charlotte went downhill in the second half of its 13 episodes. But first, I'm going to talk about what is the issue with the first half. I have mentioned the first half was episodic and yeah it was entertaining but then I began to question where all of this is getting into. And it started to feel like the value of the show is getting less interesting with overuse gags and similar outcomes of what they are doing. But then finally something big and serious happened around episode 5 or 6 and my interest rise up again, but after that......





the pacing got rushed like Usain Bolt running for his life.



When things have gotten serious is where everything has gotten worse. The turn of events was all so sudden, resolving main issues turned out to be as easy as solving kindergarten math, and the drama felt empty like your wallet. The story is not built for 13 episodes, but far more so the pacing could have done right. Jun Maeda made it anyway and the director improvise and messed things up, instead of making Charlotte great, they made the show look pretentious.


I'm not going to mention names but Charlotte turned into romance in the second half. Anyone doesn't mind romance, if done right, but not here. Yeah the cast spend much time with each other in the first half but there was no indication or hint a romantic development is happening. In short, the romance is vague and felt unnecessary. Then again, it was because the pacing was rushed.


Lastly, Charlotte turned out to be a MC centric show, opposite of what was happening with a collaborative group effort in the first half of the series. Yuu had a big revelation with his power and did everything himself. Why even bother making characters around him then? To be his determination to accomplish his goal? Yeah and One Piece is successful because Luffy doesn't rely on his crew.....


Ok enough about that, I'm getting tired of discussing how bad the direction went in the second half of the series. I'm now going to discuss the other, slightly positive elements Charlotte can offer you.



Characters: The Positive.
